Their interaction seemed way too flirty for a client trainer relationship. My friend Sarah mentioned seeing Mia and Marcus at a coffee shop looking very cozy. I hired a private investigator, the same one Kenny had.

Guy at my gym kept stealing the five Velveeta plates, so I made sure he couldn't find them. I've been going to the same gym for three years and there's this one guy who's made it his personal mission to ruin everyone's workout. He doesn't grunt too loud or drop weights from shoulder height or leave puddles of sweat on the bench. He does something way worse. He hoards every single 5 pounder plate in the entire building like they're made of solid gold and he's preparing for some kind of apocalypse. Our gym is small, really small. Two squat racks, three benches, a cable machine that squeaks and a row of treadmills that sound like they're about to explode any second. We only have six 5 lb plates total in the whole place. That's it, six. Most people don't even need them that often, but when you're warming up or trying to add just a little bit of weight to ease into a heavier lift without jumping up too fast, they're absolutely essential. They're the difference between a good workout and a pulled muscle. This guy, though, he'll load four of them on each side of his bar even when he's only benching 95 pounds total. Just use a 10 pound plate or a 20 or literally anything else that makes sense. But no, he needs his precious tower of five stacked up like Legos on each side of the barbell. He puts them on one at a time. Too like he's performing some kind of sacred ritual that requires perfect balance and concentration. And if you politely ask to borrow just one while he's sitting on the bench scrolling through Instagram between sets, he looks at you like you just insulted his mother and says, I'm using it all 8 of them simultaneously. Even the ones literally sitting on the floor by his feet untouched for 5 minutes straight. I tried being patient. I tried asking nicely. I tried coming at different times of day to avoid him. Nothing worked. He was always there, always hoarding, always acting like he owned the place. Last Tuesday, I finally snapped. I finished my bench press and noticed two 5 lbier plates just sitting there abandoned on the ground near the squat rack. He was all the way across the room doing cable flies, completely focused on watching himself in the mirror and checking his phone between every single rep. Perfect opportunity. I grabbed both plates, walked as casually as possible to the yoga corner in the back of the gym and shoved them behind the foam rollers and under a stack of purple yoga mats that nobody ever uses. Then I sat down right there and pretended to stretch my hamstrings for a few minutes. So.

My wedding dress pocket contained proof that my fiance was expecting someone else's baby. All I ever wanted from my wedding dress was pockets. Something that sounds trivial until you understand that having somewhere to put my hands made me feel grounded during stressful moments. When I finally found the perfect gown with hidden seams in the silk, I cried in the fitting room because I could finally envision my entire future unfolding exactly as I dreamed. My relationship with Nathan had weathered incredible challenges over our five year journey together. I'd relocated across the country to build our life together, supported him through his mother's cancer battle, and stayed by his side during a brutal period of unemployment and depression. Passion that nearly broke us both. When he finally proposed by hiding my engagement ring inside my favorite worn paperback novel, every struggle felt worthwhile. The morning of our wedding, my seamstress delivered the freshly pressed gown. While my bridesmaids went to grab breakfast, I was alone in the bridal suite, carefully steaming the dress and preparing for the most important day of my life. Almost automatically, I slipped my hands into those precious pockets that had sealed my decision to choose this particular dress. My fingers touched something unexpected. Thick textured paper that definitely hadn't been there. During my final fitting, I pulled out what appeared to be a medical document, thinking perhaps Nathan had orchestrated another romantic surprise. Like the hidden ring in my beloved book, my Heart actually leaped with anticipation of another sweet gesture. Instead, I found myself staring at a sonogram image with a handwritten message scrolled across the back. Sorry. I thought you deserve to know. He doesn't even know I'm keeping it. No signature, no explanation. the devastating revelation that my fiance was going to be a father with someone else entirely. Standing there in my wedding suite, I felt my entire world collapse in slow motion. Every late night Nathan had blamed on traffic, every unexplained work trip, every time he'd insisted he wasn't ready for children. While I swallowed my disappointment. Suddenly, everything made perfect, horrible sense. The woman carrying his child had felt compelled to warn me before I made the biggest mistake of my life. I didn't scream or faint or throw anything across the room. I simply stood there, slowly suffocating under the weight of this anonymous stranger's conscience. She'd known I was getting married and couldn't let me walk down that aisle without understanding exactly who I was promising to spend forever with. For guilt had become my salvation. I carefully folded the sonogram back into the dress pocket where she'd hidden it, zipped the gown into its protective bag, and walked out of the hotel in the same comfortable flats I'd planned to wear during our reception dancing. The irony wasn't lost on me that the pockets I'd always dreamed of had become the hiding place for my worst nightmare. Nathan texted hours later, Asking where I disappeared to probably fielding questions from confused wedding guests about his missing bride, I simply replied that he should check the pocket in my wedding dress, the same place his pregnant girlfriend had left her confession. I knew he'd understand immediately what that meant. His response came much later, a desperate message begging me to trust him and come back so we could talk through everything. But he never denied the sonogram or claimed it was some kind of misunderstanding which told me everything I needed to.

What broke your heart and restored your faith in humanity at the same time? A 13 year old offered me his entire savings just to come to his birthday party, saying you don't have to bring a present or anything. No one else is going anyway. He shoved a piece of paper at me and started backing away. It was a handmade invitation with crayon borders and his name written carefully in the middle, Joshua turning 13. I ruffled up his hair and smiled. I'll be there, kid. His eyes lit up and his lips formed the biggest grin. It's on Saturday. I'll save you some cake, he shouted before running off excitedly towards his parents in one of the grocery aisles yelling, I got one, I got one. I looked back at the invitation in my hand feeling my heartbreak, remembering him say no one else is going. After work. I drove by Joshua's address that night and saw one sad balloon tied to the mailbox and I knew I couldn't just leave things like this. I mentioned the party to my family over dinner and they all got the Joshua look on their faces. We're going, my sister said immediately. Even my parents nodded. I texted a few friends too. That's when things got out of hand. My friend posted in our town Facebook group while I was asleep, this kid is turning 13 on Saturday and literally no one is coming to his party. Anyone free 2 To 4, I woke up to my phone buzzing non stop. Someone had made a group chat called Joshua's Birthday Squad and it already had 47 people already excited for the surprise. My daughter's using her allowance to buy him a present. Who's bringing balloons? Get the cake. Even the local pizza place owner was there offering 10 free boxes on the house. The high school football team was arguing about who got to carry in the cake and a retired magician offered to give the best show in town. People were tagging their friends, their neighbours, their co workers. Get everyone, someone wrote. I sat there staring at my phone already grinning just thinking about little Joshua's reaction. I told the group, everyone meet at the park at 2:15. We'll walk over together. When I got to the park, I couldn't believe it. Nearly 50 people were there with presents, balloons and the pizza guy had a tower of boxes. Ready, guys, they nodded. I texted the number on Joshua's invitation, letting him know I'd be running a little late. Joshua.

My parents left a note. Weddings off. Expect a call from my lawyer. I replied, understood. Then I called the bank. Freeze the account. Those funds are disputed. Forty eight hours later, I had six, seven missed calls. Two weeks before my wedding, I found a note on my parents kitchen counter. Mom's sharp handwriting. The same script I'd seen on birthday cards for years. No explanation, no signature. Just silence. I texted back one word understood. But that wasn't the worst part. My cousin Kourtney sent me a screenshot of a group chat titled Monroe Family Wedding Changes. My heart stopped as I read the names. Mom, Dad had my younger sister, Sage, who'd gotten engaged three months ago. They weren't canceling my wedding, they were reassigning it. Same venue I toured for months, same guest list, same photographer. Sage was now the bride, wearing my plans like a stolen dress. The florist invoice from Magnolia Gardens showed my name crossed out in red pen. Sage Monroe, written above it in Mom's familiar handwriting. The photographer's revised timeline listed Sage and Eric as the couple. My deposit transferred to their account. I stared at the group chat messages, reading each betrayal word by word. Sage had joked, at least now the photos will actually be cute. Mom replied with three heart emojis and can't wait to see you in white. Sweet. My vision blurred with the kind of fury that comes when someone peels your skin off layer By layer. While smiling directly at your face. I trusted them with every deposit, every vendor contract, every wedding detail. Because mom insisted it would be easier to coordinate everything through one family account. Easier to erase me without a trace. I opened my laptop and created a folder labeled evidence. Wedding Theft Case. Screenshots, bank transfer receipts, signed contracts. Everything went in methodically. Over $38,000 in deposits and vendor payments, all made from my personal account, all being systematically transferred to benefit Sage's sudden wedding. But they'd made one crucial mistake. The joint account controlling everything was still in my name. I called the bank immediately. I need to freeze account No. 4, 3, 8, 7. Those funds are disputed. Reason for dispute? The rep asked. Fraud. Someone's been making unauthorized transfers without my consent. They even forged documents to move my wedding deposits. Within 20 minutes, everything was frozen. Every vendor payment, every final installment stopped. Then I called my lawyer. I need you to file an emergency injunction. Family members are stealing my wedding using my money. The evidence was overwhelming. Text messages where Sage thanked me for letting her have the better date. Email threads showing mom coordinating my replacement, bank records proving I paid for everything being transferred. Eight hours after I froze the account, my phone exploded. Six, seven missed calls, 43 texts, 12 voicemails. Mom's voicemail was frantic. Jenny, you're ruining everything. The caterer is threatening to cancel the venue. Might give away The date. Call us back immediately. Sage's text was pure rage. You psychotic bitch! You're destroying my wedding day. I'll never forgive you for this. Dad tried authority. Stop this nonsense. You're embar

I invented a fake religion to skip Christmas and accidentally started a cult with 16,000 followers. Three weeks ago I was just a 30 something guy trying to avoid the exhausting holiday drive to my parents house. Today I'm apparently the accidental founder of a rapidly growing online spiritual movement called muganism and I have absolutely no idea how to stop what I've started without disappointing thousands of people. Began with a simple phone call from my mother asking about Christmas plans. Instead of being honest about my travel fatigue or making a reasonable excuse about work obligations, I panicked completely and blurted out that I joined a new religion that doesn't celebrate Christmas. I expected her to immediately call out my obvious lie since we've never been remotely religious. Instead, my saint of a mother responded with genuine excitement about my spiritual journey and asked for details about my newfound faith. Trapped by her enthusiasm, I started improvising frantically, using random objects around my apartment for inspiration. Coffee mug became muganism, my coffee table inspired tree worship, and my brown sweater LED to wearing earth tones as religious practice. I on an elaborate mythology about tree gods being the source of life, oxygen, and spiritual wisdom, claiming we stay awake all night to commune with nature's ancient spirits. The lies flowed surprisingly easily, like I was back in college desperately improvising through an unprepared presentation. Except this time I was deceiving my loving mother about my fake spiritual awakening. Mom listened respectfully and said she was sad I wouldn't be home for Christmas, wanted to support my personal growth. I hung up, feeling like the worst son imaginable, planning to confess my deception after the holidays and resume normal family visits. I thought this ridiculous charade would quietly end with my eventual spiritual crisis and return to reason. The next day, mom called to say she'd shared my story with a lonely young neighbour who was struggling during the holiday season. This woman was apparently fascinated by mugwumpism and wanted to speak with me directly about the theology and practices. I was trapped between confessing to my mother or continuing the elaborate deception. I chose poorly and called this stranger, sharing vague mystical nonsense about trees, always watching, and developing increasingly complex lore about vengeful forest deities. When she asked about our founder, I panicked again and invented Chairman Rugford, named after a magazine on my coffee table, claiming he'd received divine revelations from Ancient Oaks. That evening, fueled by eggnog and finding the absurdity hilarious, I drunkenly created a Twitter account for Chairman Rugford. I posted several tweets about our limbs originating from trees, our bones eventually becoming bird nests, allowing our spirits to transform into Woodland guardians. It seemed harmlessly ridiculous at the time. I woke up to discover the account had gained 90 followers overnight. The neighbour I'd spoken with had a significant social media presence and had enthusiastically promoted Chairman Rugger's wisdom to her thousands of Followers

My parents sold my sports car to fund my sister's London trip. When my mom bragged, I said that was not mine. She went pale. I'm Sarah, 28, and I've spent my entire life being the responsible daughter while my sister Emma, 25, played the role of the spoiled princess. Growing up, I worked part time jobs through high school and college, saved every penny and never asked for handouts. she's never held a job longer than two weeks and still lives at home constantly demanding money from our parents. Last year, I finally achieved my dream. After three years of working 60 hour weeks at a tech company and living off ramen noodles, I bought my dream car, a gorgeous red Mustang convertible. I was so proud, posting pictures everywhere, taking weekend drives just to feel the wind in my hair. Emma's reaction, pure jealousy. She immediately started her usual manipulation tactics, crying to our parents that it wasn't fair I had something nice while she was struggling. Mom and dad, as always, took her side. They suggested I should share the car or help Emma get one too. I politely declined. This was my achievement. The complaints didn't stop. Every family dinner became about Emma's transportation needs. She dramatically sigh about taking the bus, shoot dirty looks at my car keys and make passive aggressive comments about some people being selfish with family. Two weeks ago, I left for a crucial business trip to Tokyo, a potential Promotion was on the line. I'd worked months preparing for this presentation. My Mustang stayed safely parked at the airport and I flew out feeling confident about my future. Day 3 of my trip, I'm in a meeting when my phone buzzes with text from Emma. Pictures of London landmarks, expensive restaurants, designer shopping bags. Then a call. Sarah, thank you so much for the London vacation, mom says. You're such a generous sister. My blood turned to ice. What vacation? What are you talking about? The luxury trip, two weeks in London, staying at the Ritz, unlimited shopping budget. Mom sold your car to pay for it, he said, you totally understand because family comes first and you can always buy another car with your fancy job. I felt like I've been punched in the stomach. They sold my car without even calling me. Well, yeah, but it's for a good cause. I really needed this. After Marcus broke up with me, mom said you'd want to help your little sister heal. I hung up immediately and called my parents, my hands shaking with rage. Mom answered cheerfully like nothing was wrong. Hi, honey. How's Tokyo? Oh.

My boyfriend said I was too high maintenance, so I showed him what low maintenance really looks like. I've been dating Logan for 14 months. I sent him my usual good morning text with heart emojis, then asked if he could grab my anxiety meds since I couldn't leave the hospital. My mom had been diagnosed with cancer and I've been at the hospital supporting her everyday. This is exactly what I'm talking about. He snapped through the phone. The constant texts, I love yous, the emotional updates. Now errands. You're so high maintenance and exhausting. My ex never needed this much reassurance or help. I stared at my mom hooked up to I V. Drips while other people's boyfriends brought them coffee and held their hands in the waiting room. Logan, my mom literally has cancer and I can't leave. See? Always drama, always needing validation and support. I need a low maintenance girlfriend who doesn't drain me emotionally. I watched a nurse adjust my mom's morphine while tears burned my eyes. You know what? You're absolutely right. Low maintenance it is. Finally, you get it. This will be so much healthier for both of us. The way he said both of us while I sat alone in a cancer ward made me realise what I needed to do. The transformation started immediately. When Logan texted love you that night, I responded with a thumbs up emoji. Nothing else. The next week he got promoted at his job. Usually I plan a whole Celebration dinner, make reservations and buy champagne. This time, I sent congrats with zero punctuation, zero emojis, zero enthusiasm. He seemed confused, but said nothing. The real show began at his best friend's dinner party. When Knox mentioned how Logan lucked out with such a caring girlfriend, I laughed genuinely. Oh, god, no. I used to be such an emotional burden, constantly texting him like some desperate stalker, saying I love you like a broken record, planning all these suffocating surprises. But Logan showed me how exhausting I was being. I barely even noticed him most days. The entire table went silent. Logan's face turned red. Knox's wife looked between us. Logan reached for my hand under the table. I pulled away, looking concerned. Babe, why are you being so needy in public? I thought we agreed that was unhealthy. His friends exchanged glances. Ox cleared his throat uncomfortably. My mom needed emergency surgery the following Tuesday. I went alone. When Logan found out three days later from my Instagram story thanking the nurses, he was furious. Why didn't you tell me your mom had surgery? I tilted my head, confused. Why are you being so nosy about my personal medical business? That's really invasive and needy. Logan, that's not what I meant. You literally said medical updates were exhausting. Now you're demanding them? Pick a lane, dude. I stopped initiating any physical contact. No hand holding, no kisses. Unless he started them. And even then, I'd pull away after two seconds. When he complained about his stressful merger at work, I set my phone timer. You've got five minutes to vent and we're done with emotional stuff for the week. He thought I was joking until the alarm went off mid sentence and I started talking.

How did your dad lose his custody rights? I was 12 when a tornado warning Siren went off at 2:00am. Most kids never think about what their parents would actually do in a real emergency until it happens. I found out the hard way. The sirens were screaming outside our house and I could hear the wind picking up something fierce. I'd done tornado drills at school a million times. Teacher always said the same thing, have a plan with your family. Nowhere to go, stick together. So when I heard that awful wailing sound, I did exactly what I was supposed to do. I ran straight to my parents bedroom, heart pounding in my chest. The door was already open and mom was frantically pulling clothes out of dresser drawers while dad grabbed boxes from under the bed. Grab the photo albums, mom shouted at him, pointing to the bookshelf. What about me, I asked, standing there in my pajamas with my hair all messy from sleep. Neither one of them even looked at me. Dad rushed past me carrying our old wedding albums and some jewellery boxes. Mom was right behind him with her arms full of important papers and more pictures. I followed them downstairs, my bare feet cold on the hardwood floor. I could hear the thunder getting louder outside and the rain was starting to hammer against the windows. The emergency radio was crackling with warnings about rotation. Spotted just a few miles away when We got to the basement door. Mom turned around and saw me standing there. There's no more room, she snapped. I was asking for something unreasonable. Then they shut the door right in my face. I stood there in that dark hallway alone while the whole house shook from thunder. The sirens kept wailing and I could hear the wind outside getting stronger and stronger. It sounded like a freight train was coming straight for us. I tried knocking on the basement door, but they didn't answer. I called for them, but nothing. So I crawled under the kitchen table with Buster, our old golden retriever, and wrap my arms around him. He was shaking just as bad as I was. That's when it really hit me. If that tornado came through our neighborhood, my parents weren't going to open that door for me. They'd rather save their stupid photo albums than make sure their own daughter was safe. The storm lasted about 20 minutes, but it felt like hours. When the sirens finally stopped and the wind died down, I heard the basement door creek open. Mom and dad came upstairs looking all annoyed like the whole thing had just been a big inconvenience. You should have knocked harder, mom said, when she saw me still under the table. You could have been hurt if you came down with all that stuff, dad added, gesturing to their precious boxes. You'll thank us one day when we still have the Photo albums mom finished, but I didn't thank them. Not that.

My daughter blocked me after the divorce, then contacted me eight years later asking for her inheritance. When I tested her motives, she showed her true colours. I divorced my wife, Patricia eight years ago when my daughter Chloe was 20. Despite everything that happened, Chloe cut all contact with me and chose her mother's side without even asking for my perspective. The divorce was devastating enough, but being completely shut out from my daughter's life was harder than anything else I'd experienced. I contacted Chloe several times after the divorce, but she was dead set on supporting her mom and wouldn't hear my side of the story. Eventually, Patricia threatened to sue me for harassment if I didn't leave our daughter alone, which made everything Crystal clear. I spent the last eight years caring for my mother who had alzheimer's while focusing on my career. I've had casual relationships here and there but struggle to fully trust anyone after the divorce devastation. We recently reached out after all this time. I was over the moon thinking she'd finally come to her senses and understood the divorce wasn't entirely my fault. This felt especially comforting since my mother had recently passed away and I've been dealing with that grief alone. Desperate for family connection, Chloe called from an unknown number several months after mom died, saying she saw on social media that her grandmother passed and wanted to check on me. I was shocked since I didn't know she kept Tabs on me online but thought it was sweet of her to call. We arranged dinner at my house over the weekend and I was genuinely excited about reconnecting after nearly a decade apart. When Chloe arrived for dinner, I didn't recognize her at first since it had been so long. We started talking and though initially awkward, both of us opened up after a while. After dinner, we finally addressed the elephant in the room. I asked why she never bothered listening to my side during the divorce and chose her mom by default. My daughter said she regretted how things turned out, that she was too young to think clearly and got manipulated by how her mother presented everything. Patricia had painted me as the ultimate bad guy who didn't care about anyone except himself. And since Chloe never heard my perspective, she never questioned whatever her mom said. We talked more about this and things seem to be going well until she finally revealed why she was really there. We've been talking for hours. When I asked what made her reach out after all these years, she looked uncomfortable but said she could be honest with me. Then she explained she'd been keeping tabs on me through social media and when she found out her grandmother died, she expected lawyers to contact her about inheritance. When no one did, she thought she should reach out personally. She said she'd recently gotten engaged and could really use some Money to help with wedding expenses. It felt like getting punched in the gut. I thought after all these years, my prayers were answered and I could have family again. But it turned out she never cared about me in the first place. It was all just a way to get her inheritance. The ironic part is it's not even legally her inheritance. It's all mine. And if she hadn't been such a terrible daughter, she definitely would have ended up with most, if not all of it. I decided to test her intentions by seeing how she'd react if I told her there was no money to inherit. I asked how much she expected from the inheritance, and she made quite an accurate guess that showed some planning had gone into this whole reunion. Then I told her I was sorry to disappoint, but her grandmother actually left everything to me here.

What broke your heart and restored your faith in humanity at the same time? A 13 year old offered me his entire savings just to come to his birthday party, saying, you don't have to bring a present or anything. No one else is going anyway. He shoved a piece of paper at me and started backing away. It was a handmade invitation with crayon borders and his name written carefully in the middle Joshua turning 13. I ruffled up his hair and smiled. I'll be there, kid! His eyes lit up and his lips formed the biggest grin. It's on Saturday! I'll save you some cake! He shouted before running off excitedly towards his parents in one of the grocery aisles, yelling I got one! I got one! I looked back at the invitation in my hand, feeling my heartbreak remembering him say no one else is going. After work, I drove by Joshua's address that night and saw one sad balloon tied to the mailbox, and I knew I couldn't just leave things like this. I mentioned the party to my family over dinner and they all got the Joshua look on their faces. We're going! My sister said immediately. Even my parents nodded. I texted a few friends too. That's when things got out of hand. My friend posted in our town Facebook group while I was asleep this kid is turning 13 on Saturday and literally no one is coming to his party. And anyone free 2 to 4, I woke up to my phone buzzing non stop. Someone had made a group chat called Joshua's Birthday Squad, and it already had 47 people already excited for the surprise. My daughter's using her allowance to buy him a present. Who's bringing balloons? I'll get the cake. Even the local pizza place owner was there, offering 10 free boxes on the house. The high school football team was arguing about who got to carry in the cake, and a retired magician offered to give the best show in town. People were tagging their friends, their neighbours, their co workers. Get everyone, someone wrote. I sat there staring at my phone, already grinning, just thinking about little Joshua's reaction. Told the group, everyone meet at the park at 2:15. We'll walk over together. When I got to the park, I couldn't believe it. Nearly 50 people were there with presents, balloons, and the pizza guy had a tower of boxes. Ready, guys? They nodded. I texted the number on Joshua's invitation, letting him know I'd be running a little late. Joshua texted back immediately, it's okay if you changed your mind, Mister. Little did he know what was coming. We walked to Joshua's house as this massive parade. I rang the doorbell and heard Joshua's feet rushing towards the door. He's here! He yelled to his parents before opening the door. His mouth instantly hung open when he saw a huge crowd of people right behind me. Nope. We're here. His face went through about five different emotions. Confusion, shock. Then his eyes just

My fiance said, I'm not ready for a commitment. I replied, I understand. Then I sold the engagement ring and used my share of the wedding fund to start a company with my best friend. We were eating Thai food on the couch when Catherine muted the TV and turned to me with that look that makes your stomach drop. I can't do this, she said, tears. Starting the wedding us, I not ready for a commitment. I need to find myself. Four months before our wedding, 30 thousand dollars in our joint wedding fund, 12 thousand dollar custom engagement ring on her finger. I didn't scream or beg. I just looked at her and said, I understand. The next week was hell, canceling vendors, calling family, splitting our finances. At the coffee shop where we divided everything, she slid the engagement ring across the table. Do whatever you want with it, she said, unable to meet my eyes. So I did. I sold it for $7,000 The next day. That night, my best friend Sean came over. He's a brilliant coder stuck at a soul crushing I t help desk and we dreamed of starting a software consultancy for years. He saw the check on my table next to my laptop showing my account balance, $42,000 total. My $15,000 from the wedding fund, $7,000 from the ring and $20,000 I'd saved for a house down payment. Dude, this is it, Sean said. This is our shot. It was terrifying. To bet everything on a startup. But looking at my empty apartment, I realized a blank page isn't just scary, it's opportunity. Let's do it. Six months of coffee, pizza and pure adrenaline, we worked out of my spare bedroom under bidding on small projects just to build our portfolio. That $42,000 was our lifeline. Only it worked. We landed bigger contracts. By year one, we had a real office. By year 2, we'd hired our first employees. I hadn't heard from Catherine in two years. I blocked her everywhere. Heard through mutual friends she was finding herself traveling Asia with some artist boyfriend. Then a local business blog featured us as a bootstrap success story. The article included a photo of me and Sean looking exhausted but proud in our office. Phone buzz, unknown number. I saw the article. You look good, Catherine. More texts followed. I've been thinking about us. I made a terrible mistake. I see the man you've become and I want to be with him. I didn't respond, but she didn't stop. She showed up at a tech meet up where she knew I'd be, cornered me in the hallway crying about how she'd thrown away the only real thing in her life. I want to be part of it, she pleaded, gesturing toward my success. Your partner in every way. There it was. She didn't miss me. She missed my trajectory. Catherine, you forfeited your right to be part of my life. I said, Calmly. You wanted independence. I gave you that. Now respect my decision. Her tears stopped like a faucet turning off. That was our wedding money, money for our future. No, it was money in a joint account we legally divided. You used your half for Thailand with.

Boyfriend wanted me to pretend we weren't together at his work party. My boyfriend Nathan told me this while we were getting ready for his company holiday party tonight. We need to act like we're not together, he said. While messing with his watch. I stopped putting on my makeup and look at him. What? Just don't tell anyone you're my girlfriend. Don't hold my hand. Don't stand near me. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. We've been together for two years. Why? He let out this annoyed sigh like I was being ridiculous. My boss only promotes single guys. He thinks relationships make you weak, less focused. I, I've been telling him I'm single since I started gunning for this promotion three months ago. I felt my stomach drop. Three months of lying about me. He said everyone brings plus one, so it would look weird if he came alone. But I had to pretend to be someone from his apartment building. The promotion decision was Monday. I looked at him in the mirror and felt something shift inside me. I put on my earrings real slow. Okay, Nathan, whatever you need. The second we got there, Nathan walked in way ahead of me, like he didn't even know me. I headed straight to the bar where his coworker Brian was getting a drink. I don't think we've met, Brian said with a friendly smile. I'm Nathan's neighbor from his building. It was the cover story Nathan wanted. Brian smiled bigger and got me a drink. We were talking for about 20 minutes when he asked, are you seeing anyone? I looked over at Nathan, who was pretending I didn't exist. No, I'm single. Brian's whole face lit up. Wanna meet my buddy Louise from accounting? He waved over a guy from across the room. Louise was actually really charming and kept touching my arm while we talked. Nathan showed up at the bar acting like he just needed a drink. Nathan, meet this gorgeous woman who lives in your building. Louis was excited. Nathan had to shake my hand like we were complete strangers. Nice to meet you, he said, and I could hear how mad he was. You too, I said back. Louis jumped right back in. I was just about to get her number. He handed me his phone. I typed my number in while Nathan stood there, his jaw clenching. About 10 minutes later, Nathan's boss came over to our group. Who's this lovely lady? He asked with this big smile. While she's single and lives in Nathan's building, Louis announced, looking pretty proud of himself. The boss's eyes got all bright. Nathan, you seeing this? While you're focused on work, Louis is out here meeting beautiful women from your own building. Nathan forced out this fake laugh. His boss kept going, though. This is what I mean. You stay single, you stay hungry. Relationships kill ambition. No offense. Turn to me when he Said that last part. None taken. I agree completely. I was looking right at Nathan when I said it. The boss just wouldn't stop. Nathan here is my best example. Three months without a single date. That's dedication. That's why he's getting promoted. Monday, everyone raise their glasses to toast Nathan's promotion. I raise mine too. To staying single, I said, staring straight at Nathan. His hand was literally shaking when he took a drink. Luis asked me to dance after that. While we were on the dance

What's that school rule you hated the most? My school had this insane group punishment policy where if one person messed up, the entire class got detention. I thought it was stupid until it backfired spectacularly on them. It was finals week, and our notorious substitute, Mr. Miles, was covering math class. This guy lived to make students miserable. He'd already written up three kids for breathing too loud. Someone's phone buzzed during his lecture. Just once. Miles's face turned red and he slammed his book down so hard it cracked. That's it. Everyone stays after school for detention. Someone will come confess, or you all suffer. Jake tried explaining he had a doctor's appointment. Miles cut him off. I don't care if your house is burning down, you're staying. He locked the classroom door and pocketed the key, posted a note outside saying, detention in progress. Do not disturb. Miles sat at his desk playing solitaire while 32 kids stared at the clock. Two hours passed. Kids were texting parents frantically. Put those phones away, or I'll add another hour! Miles barked. Emma raised her hand. My mom's outside waiting. Can I at least tell her? Should have thought about that before someone disrupted my class. Lisa asked to use the bathroom. Denied. This is insane, I muttered. What was that? Miles stood up, pointing at me. Congratulations. You just earned everyone an extra 30 minutes. The class turned on me with a death glares. But here's what miles Didn't know my mom was the district superintendent. She was probably wondering why I wasn't home yet. At six PM, Miles finally unlocked the door. Maybe next time you'll think twice about disrupting class. Parents were livid in the parking lot. Cars everywhere, honking, others marching toward the building. The principal's car was gone. He'd fled. I got in my mom's car. She was already on the phone with someone. What happened? She asked, hanging up. I explained everything. Miles locking us in, refusing bathroom breaks, adding time for speaking, threatening kids who tried to leave. Her expression changed completely. She grabbed her laptop from the back seat and started typing furiously while driving. Call every parent in your class. Get their numbers now! I started texting frantically. Within minutes, my phone was exploding with angry parent responses. Conference call tonight. Eight PM, mom said. Already dialing the school board president. By nine PM, she had statements from all 32 families. Document
NA

People in arranged marriages, what's it like? My parents arranged my marriage to Priya when we were both 12. We met once at the engagement ceremony, exchanged maybe five words, then didn't see each other for six years while I finished college in Mumbai and she studied veterinary medicine and Delhi. The week before our wedding, I was absolutely terrified. I'd never had a real conversation with this girl who was about to become my wife. For the rest of my life, my friends thought I was completely insane for going through with it. They kept sending me articles about divorce rates and horror stories from Reddit about arranged marriages gone horribly wrong. My mom kept saying love will grow naturally, but I couldn't imagine loving someone I didn't even know existed. Most days, Priya and I had each other's phone numbers, but we'd never actually use them. The whole thing felt like we were about to become awkward roommates for the rest of our lives with no escape plan. But something weird happened during our first phone call three days before the wedding. She called me at midnight sounding completely panicked. if I wanted to postpone everything and run away to different countries. I said only if she wanted to do the same thing. We both admitted we were terrified but genuinely curious about each other as actual people. We decided to be completely honest about everything in our past. She told me she'd had a Serious boyfriend in college that her parents didn't know about and she was terrified of comparing me to him constantly. I admitted I'd never even kissed anyone because I knew I was getting married eventually anyway. We laughed about how complete, completely backwards that sounded in 2023. Our honeymoon was basically an intensive friendship boot camp with room service. We made a serious pact, absolutely no physical stuff until we actually liked each other as real people. We spent two weeks in Goa just talking for hours every day, playing card games and figuring out if we were actually compatible long term. The resort staff probably thought we were the weirdest newly weds they'd ever seen in their careers. Other couples were all over each other constantly while we sat on the beach having deep conversations about our dreams, fears and childhood traumas that shaped us. He wanted to be a veterinarian and save every single stray animal in India. I wanted to start a tech company but was terrified of failing spectacularly like my uncle did. Turns out we both loved terrible reality TV shows and had the exact same weird sense of humour about everything. She could make me laugh until my stomach hurt just by perfectly imitating our dramatic relatives at family gatherings. I'd never met anyone who cared about anything as.

My little sister stole my baby name and gave birth first. So I gave my daughter a name she'll never forget. I've been planning to name my daughter Sophia Rose since I was literally 14 years old. I had this whole Pinterest board with nursery ideas, wrote it in my diary about a million times, even practice signing birthday cards with love, Sophia's mom, like a complete weirdo. When I got pregnant at 23, everyone in my family knew this was the name. I've been talking about it for almost 10 years. But my younger sister Emma always had to make everything about her growing up. If I got a new bike, she needed a better one. If I made honor roll, she suddenly cared about grades. When I announced I was pregnant, she immediately started trying to get pregnant too, even though she'd been with her boyfriend Tyler for only like 8 months and could barely afford rent on her studio apartment. A few months after my announcement, she called me crying happy tears. I'm pregnant too. We can be pregnant together. At first I was excited, sister. Pregnancy sounded cute. We could share maternity clothes, compare weird cravings, complain about swollen feet together. But then she started copying everything I mentioned, craving pickles and ice cream. Suddenly that was her thing too. I bought this gorgeous cream colored crib from target. She showed up with the exact same one three days later when I posted bump photos in My favorite blue maternity dress. She bought the same dress in pink and posted almost identical pics. The worst part was she kept asking about names. What are you thinking for names? I'm so stuck. You always have the best ideas. I stupidly told her about Sophia Rose because I trusted her. She nodded along, said it was beautiful, even suggested middle name alternatives. Then at 36 weeks, he went into early labor. I was still two weeks away from my due date, feeling like a whale and scared something was wrong. She texted me from the hospital, she's here, 7 pounds, 2 ounces of perfect. Come meet your niece. I waddled into that hospital room with flowers and a pink teddy bear, so excited to meet my first niece. Emma was glowing in her hospital bed holding this tiny, perfect baby girl. Meet Sophia Rose, she said with the biggest smile. I literally felt my heart stop. What did you just say? Sophia Rose. Tyler, she repeated, like nothing was wrong. Isn't she perfect? The name just felt so right when I saw her little face. You were right. It's such a beautiful name. I stood there holding wilted flowers, 38 weeks pregnant with my own daughter, watching my sister cuddle the baby who now had my name, the name I'd planned for almost a decade. Tyler was taking pictures. The nurses were cooing, and I felt like I was watching my dreams get stolen in real time. Emma That was my name. I whispered. She.

Teacher locked away our phones during class and created her own villain origin story. Monday morning, I walk into first period English and our teacher standing there with this metal safe that has a digital timer on top, looking way too pleased with herself. Starting today, all phones go in this timer safe. It only opens 5 minutes before the bell. No exceptions. Diabetic kid immediately raises his hand about his glucose monitor app and she goes, the school has landlines. You'll survive 55 minutes without TikTok. This is three months after we had an actual lockdown, by the way. The quiet girl in back asks, what if there's an emergency? And teachers like, that's what I'm here for, girl. You're not bulletproof. So I look at my phone and I'm about to turn off my medication alarm that goes off at 9:15. But then I stop and instead open my alarm app setting three more, 9:20, 9:25, 9:30. My best friend sees what I'm doing and starts grinning like the Grinch. She whispers to the person next to them. I look around and everyone's phones are suspiciously active. The athletes typing frantically, theater kids changing ringtones, anime fans doing something unhinged with notifications. We're all making eye contact like we're planning a heist. The teacher comes around to collect our phones and locks the safe. The timer shows 50 minutes, she says, see, now we can focus on learning without distractions. Ma'am, you just played yourself. Ten minutes into Class. My anxiety medication alarm goes off. Be be, be from inside the safe during her pop quiz. She tries to ignore it but it gets louder. Sorry, that's my medication reminder. I take it at 9:15 exactly or I get panic attacks, I explain. She goes to tell me to turn it off then realizes, oh, the alarm screams for two full minutes before auto stopping. 15 minutes later, the chaos truly begins. Someone's Kim possible notification goes off. What's the stitch? Over. Over and over again. Theater Kid claims it's their vocal warm up reminder. Then the Imperial March starts playing. The Quiet Girl deadpan says, my dad insists on having a Star Wars ringtone. He must be calling. Then someone's phone starts blasting. Pressure pushing down on me. And the athlete goes, coach only calls with Queen. He's weird. 20 minutes in and it's giving fandom convention full anime opening songs start playing. Unclear which one, but definitely shun in the office theme song kicks in. Someone's notification is just Minecraft villager noises on repeat. Her, her. The safe is literally vibrating across the teacher's desk. 25 minutes in and we've reached chaotic good territory. Soda pop from K Pop Demon Hunters starts blasting and this girl goes, that's my bias birthday reminder. Once Baby Shark starts playing, the teacher looks ready to cry. 30 minutes in, the door opens. It's the teacher from.

What happened when you met a deaf girl at your cousin's wedding three years ago? At my cousin's wedding, I knocked over this girl's drink. Reaching across the buffet table, I apologized for 30 seconds straight before realizing she was pointing at her ears and signing something I didn't understand. My cousin texted me later that night. That was Annalise. She lost her hearing from meningitis when she was 6. He sent her Instagram. She asked about the guy who kept talking to himself at the say. I scrolled through videos of her signing stories, her face animated and expressive. In one video, she taught basic signs. I watched it over and over trying to copy her hand movements. She looks so confident, so comfortable in her silence. I messaged her two days later, I'm the idiot who wouldn't stop apologizing at the wedding. Can I buy you a replacement drink? She replied with laughing emojis. You mean the guy who gave a whole speech to a deaf person? Then added, yes, but only if you bring a notepad. This time at the coffee shop, we typed messages back and forth on our phones. Annalise told me her parents never Learned ASL after she went deaf. They still think hearing aids solve everything, like glasses for your ears. When she laughed, her whole face lit up. I forgot to read her next message until she waved her hand at me. Stop staring, weirdo, I typed back. Sorry, you're distracting. She Rolled her eyes but smiled. We stayed until they kicked us out of closing. After that date, I downloaded every ASL app I could find. I practiced finger spelling during my commute, signed to myself in mirrors. My roommate caught me signing in my sleep. Dude, are you cursing someone out? I was apparently signing banana repeatedly. Annalise sent me daily sign tutorials. Today's phrase, I'm hopeless at this. I sent videos of my attempts. She responded, you just signed, I'm pregnant with fish. Please try again. Within 6 months, I could hold conversations. Annalise introduced me to her deaf friends at a game night. Everyone signed so fast, my eyes couldn't keep. But her friend signed something that made everyone laugh. Annalise translated. She says, you signed with an accent, like a baby accent. I tried signing back. At least I'm trying. More laughter. Annalise fixed my hands. You just said you're crying. Close enough. Two years in, we moved in together. I was fluent by then. Our apartment.

While I was swimming at the pool, the lifeguard asked me, when do you think you'll drown? I can float for a couple minutes. Why don't move and don't leave the water no matter what? We need to clear it and evacuate everyone else, but you need to stay. What's in the water? My voice came out shaky. He didn't answer. Instead, he raised his whistle and blew three sharp blasts that echoed across the pool area. Everyone out of the pool immediately. This is not a drill. Family started rushing toward the ladders and stairs in a chaotic scramble. Kids were crying as parents hold the mount. Water splashing everywhere. The shallow end emptied in seconds as people grabbed their belongings and ran. I wanted to join them, but I was stuck floating in 12 feet of water trying not to move. Hold still. The lifeguard kept his eyes locked on the water around me. I was trying my best, but my arms were already getting tired from the careful balancing. The sun beat down and without movement, the water felt colder. Some families had stopped at the fence instead of leaving completely. A few called out encouragement, telling me to relax and breathe and stay as, as possible. Others had their phones out recording whatever was happening. I could see the little red lights pointing at me from multiple angles. Three other lifeguards appeared with long handled nets used for cleaning debris. They spread out around different parts. Of the pool, moving slowly and carefully. The one nearest to me kept a net raised, ready to strike at something. Their faces were all focused on the water like they were hunting. My breathing quickened despite trying to stay calm. Something was in the pool with me, something dangerous enough to evacuate everyone else but keep me frozen in place. The lifeguards crept along the edges, scanning every inch of water. One of the lifeguards near the diving board suddenly plunged his net into the water. He struggled with something heavy, pulling and twisting the pole. The other guards rushed over to help, leaving me unwatched for terrifying seconds. Together, they hauled up their catch and my blood went cold. An alligator thrashed in the net, not huge, but big enough at maybe 4 feet. Its tail whipped back and forth as they struggled to control it. The crowd of the fence gasped and more phones came out. Someone called animal control while the guards carefully carried the netted gator toward the bullhouse. But the lifeguard assigned to me didn't relax. He kept scanning the water around me with the same intensity. That's when I understood if there was one, there might be more. Can I get out now? My voice cracked with ear. Not yet. Stay still. He pointed to something in the deep end. Dark shadow moved along the bottom, slow and purposeful, much bigger than the one they'd caught. The guards saw it, too. They all Shifted positions, trying to get an angle with their nets, but it was too deep, too far from the edges. It's circling under her, one of them said quietly. My whole body trembled, sending ripples across the surface. The shadow continued its lazy patrol of the deep end, sometimes closer to the surface where I could make out its historic shape, sometimes deeper, where it became just a dark blur against the blue. Then someone in the crowd screamed, there's another one in the shallow end. All heads turned to see a smaller gator that had been hiding near the steps. It must have been there the whole time while families evacuated right past it. One lifeguard ran over with his net while the others stayed focused on the one beneath me.
NA

Did your family realise you weren't a little kid anymore? I'm 23 and my family still cuts my food for me at restaurants. Not kidding. My mom will literally reach over and slice my chicken into bite size pieces while I'm eating it. Growing up as the youngest of seven kids by a huge gap didn't help. My siblings are all 10, 15 years older than me. So they've always treated me like they're living at family dinners. They still ask if I need help tying my shoes or if I remember to brush my teeth. My sister Amanda still tries to help me order at restaurants, telling servers she'll have the chicken nuggets without asking what I want. Last month at my cousin Abigail's wedding was the absolute worst. The whole extended family was there, aunts, uncles, grandparents, great aunts, family, friends. The worst, during cocktail hour, my Aunt Janet loudly announced that I couldn't have champagne because babies don't drink alcohol. She handed me a juice box instead. A juice box at a wedding? I'm 23 years old with a medical degree. Then came dinner seating. My uncle Mark grabbed my arm and said, come on, sweetie, you're sitting at the kids table. I tried to protest, explaining I was an adult, but he was already walking me over to a table full of actual children. Eight year olds coloring on placemats, 10 year olds playing with action figures and me with my college degree and my job. That none of them bothered asking about. The kids kept asking me questions like what grade are you in and do you like our colouring books? I spent the entire dinner helping a sick six year old nephew cut his chicken while my family laughed from the adult tables, pointing and taking photos like it was cute. My cousin Kelly walked over during appetizers. Ah, look at you helping the little ones, she cooed. Maybe someday you'll be ready for grown up conversations. She patted my head like I was a golden retriever. The breaking point came during cake cutting. When the bride and groom finished their ceremonial first slice, they started serving guests. My Uncle Mark walked over with a plate and a plastic fork. A plastic fork. Let me help you with this, honey, he said, and started cutting my slice into tiny little pieces like I was a toddler who might choke. Uncle Mark, I can careful with the fork, sweetie. He interrupted, taking it from my hands. We don't want any accidents. Remember what happened at Christmas when you tried to use the good silverware? I hadn't dropped anything at Christmas. He was just making stuff up. The entire reception was staring at this point. Other guests were whispering and pointing. Some were filming with their phones. I felt my face burning with embarrassment. That's when the bridesmaid of honour walked over. She was this elegant woman in her 40s looking confused. Excuse me, are you Doctor Nguyen, she asked, staring directly at me. Everyone at nearby tables turned to look. My Aunt Janet burst out laughing like this was the funniest thing she'd ever heard. Oh, honey, that's just our baby cousin, she said condescendingly. She's still figuring out college classes and living in the dorms, playing dress up as a doctor. Aren't you, sweetie? The woman's face went from confused to absolutely shocked. Ma'am, this is Doctor Enoguyen. She performed emergency brain surgery on my six year old daughter.

My ex told everyone I was too boring to date and it became the best thing that ever happened to me. Surprise, this is an intervention, my best friend Jules said with a grin after lying to me about having a casual hangout this weekend. You told me we were watching Netflix, I said, looking at the fancy cocktail dress she had on. Honestly, I should have known better. Jules never did anything casually. She flipped on the t. V. And sat me on the couch. You can still have your Netflix, but tonight you're going out with me. When I complained, she reminded me just how long I've been crying about my ex. It's been three months. You need a break. I shook my head furiously while she applied makeup to my face and said, I'm not ready. She grabbed my shoulders and looked me in the eyes. There's a rooftop party upstairs. You'll meet nice people, good wine, zero pressure and forget about your stupid ex and the mean thing, he said. Got it. And if you can't do this for you, then do it for me. Give me back the bestie I know and love. I sighed and closed my eyes, letting them work their magic at the rooftop. I tried to blend into the background, but Jules's cousin Dustin spotted me immediately. You must be the famous best friend, he said, smiling warmly. Jules talks about you constantly. This is my business partner, Mark. And there He was tall and dreamy. Mark was the kind of guy I imagined when reading romance novels. So what brings you to Dustin's party? Mark asked after we'd grabbed drinks and found a quieter corner. I laughed nervously. Honestly, Jules ambushed me, told me we were having a Netflix night and then attacked me with a curling iron. I gestured at my dress. This is all her doing. I haven't been out in months. Bad breakup, he asked gently. I nodded, looking down at my feet. No, I get it. My ex told me I was too serious because I didn't want to do shots on a Tuesday. He smiled. But for what it's worth, Jules has excellent taste. You look beautiful. I felt my face flush. I feel like I'm playing dress up. Well, you're very good at it, he said, his cheeks turning red the moment our eyes locked. We stood there for a moment, that perfect awkward pause where you both know something's happening. He was about to say something else when I heard a familiar voice behind me say, wow, look at you. This isn't like you at all. I felt all the hairs on my body stick up. My ex, Craig, stood there. Well, well, look who finally left the house. He stepped forward, stretching his arms out to hug me. Mark stepped in front and held his hand out professionally. Mark and you are. Craig nodded with a smile like he was start proud. Look at you. You got yourself a looker. But I'd be careful, Mark. That dress, the makeup, the whole confident act, it's not her. Trust me, I fell for it, too. He gestured at me like I was a fraud. Mark shrugged, reaching his hand to hold mine. Thanks. But I'm happy getting to know her myself now, if you don't mind. Craig ignored him completely and started on his rant about me. Did she tell you she won't sleep with you for months? She has all these rules about dating, about building trust. First, he actually used air quotes. But the truth is, she's boring. She won't go out to clubs with you. No big social events. Instead of flirting and fun, she wants to talk about your feelings and future. Craig laughed loudly, catching everyone's attention in the room. Oh, and get this, Craig continued, clearly enjoying himself. She has an actual bedtime even on weekends. She'll bore you to death in a month, just like she did to me. I felt my tears quickly filling my eyes. The confidence Jules had helped me find was dissolving. Mark was seeing the real me now, the boring girl who couldn't keep her boyfriend.

While I was swimming at the pool, the lifeguard asked me, when do you think you'll drown? I can float for a couple minutes. Why don't move and don't leave the water no matter what? We need to clear it and evacuate everyone else, but you need to stay. What's in the water? My voice came out shaky. He didn't answer. Instead, he raised his whistle and blew three sharp blasts that echoed across the pool area. Everyone out of the pool immediately. This is not a drill. Family started rushing toward the ladders and stairs in a chaotic scramble. Kids were crying as parents hold the mount. Water splashing everywhere. The shallow end emptied in seconds as people grabbed their belongings and ran. I wanted to join them, but I was stuck floating in 12 feet of water trying not to move. Hold still. The lifeguard kept his eyes locked on the water around me. I was trying my best, but my arms were already getting tired from the careful balancing. The sun beat down and without movement, the water felt colder. Some families had stopped at the fence instead of leaving completely. A few called out encouragement, telling me to relax and breathe and stay as, as possible. Others had their phones out recording whatever was happening. I could see the little red lights pointing at me from multiple angles. Three other lifeguards appeared with long handled nets used for cleaning debris. They spread out around different parts. Of the pool, moving slowly and carefully. The one nearest to me kept a net raised, ready to strike at something. Their faces were all focused on the water like they were hunting. My breathing quickened despite trying to stay calm. Something was in the pool with me, something dangerous enough to evacuate everyone else but keep me frozen in place. The lifeguards crept along the edges, scanning every inch of water. One of the lifeguards near the diving board suddenly plunged his net into the water. He struggled with something heavy, pulling and twisting the pole. The other guards rushed over to help, leaving me unwatched for terrifying seconds. Together, they hauled up their catch and my blood went cold. An alligator thrashed in the net, not huge, but big enough at maybe 4 feet. Its tail whipped back and forth as they struggled to control it. The crowd of the fence gasped and more phones came out. Someone called animal control while the guards carefully carried the netted gator toward the bullhouse. But the lifeguard assigned to me didn't relax. He kept scanning the water around me with the same intensity. That's when I understood if there was one, there might be more. Can I get out now? My voice cracked with ear. Not yet. Stay still. He pointed to something in the deep end. Dark shadow moved along the bottom, slow and purposeful, much bigger than the one they'd caught. The guards saw it, too. They all Shifted positions, trying to get an angle with their nets, but it was too deep, too far from the edges. It's circling under her, one of them said quietly. My whole body trembled, sending ripples across the surface. The shadow continued its lazy patrol of the deep end, sometimes closer to the surface where I could make out its historic shape, sometimes deeper, where it became just a dark blur against the blue. Then someone in the crowd screamed, there's another one in the shallow end. All heads turned to see a smaller gator that had been hiding near the steps. It must have been there the whole time while families evacuated right past it. One lifeguard ran over with his net while the others stayed focused on the one beneath me.

When did you accidentally expose someone's biggest lie? I was in 8th grade when Kyle, the new kids started passing out these fancy birthday invitations. They had gold glitter and said VIP guest in big letters. Kyle was always bragging about how his dad owned 5 restaurants and his mom was a model. He said they lived in this huge mansion with a pool that had a diving board and a water slide. Everyone in class was losing their minds over this party. Kyle made it sound like it was gonna be the event of the year. He handed me an invite, too. Even though we barely talked, I felt pretty special since all the popular kids were going. The invitation said Saturday at three PM Kyle had written the address by hand in messy letters. I'd never been to that part of town before, but my mom agreed to drive me even though she was working crazy overtime that week. We pulled up to the address right on time, but something was totally wrong. There were no decorations, no balloons, no cars parked outside, just this regular old house that looked kind of run down. The lawn needed cutting and the paint was peeling. My mom double checked the address. Are you sure this is right, Jordan? I pulled out the glittery invitation. Same street name, same house number. This had to be it. I walked up and rang the doorbell. This older woman answered looking confused as heck She had gray hair and was wearing a bathrobe. Can I help you, she asked. Um, hi, I'm here for Kyle's birthday party. He invited me. The woman just stared at me. Kyle? I don't know any Kyle, sweetie. My stomach dropped to my feet. My mom stepped up behind me and asked again, thinking maybe the woman misheard. But she shook her head and said no party was happening at her house. No Kyle live there either. I felt my face get.

Speed running Minecraft at 3:00am when someone joined my discord with no profile picture, just the username, please help me 2024. Before I could kick them for the spam looking name, I heard heavy breathing and what sounded like running through trees. This wasn't a gaming headset. It was someone on their phone actually running through wood in real life. Is anyone there? Please? I need gamers specifically. You're the only ones awake right now who might believe me. It was a girl maybe 16 in OR17. Completely out of breath. My first instinct was to disconnect. This had to be some elaborate ARG or prank. But then I heard something that made my blood freeze. Dogs barking, not normal barking police dog. I escaped from a conversion therapy camp in Utah, she gasped. I told my parents I ran away 3 weeks ago but I've been locked in solitary. I stole a counselor's phone when they came to give me food. I remembered this discord server from before they took me. My chat loaded, 12 viewers suddenly became 50, then 100 as people started sharing the stream. Someone typed F a K E. But then we all heard it. A man's voice shouting in the distance. He went this way. Check Sector 7. They're hunting me like an animal, she whispered. These camps are legal because parents sign custody over. If they catch me, I disappear forever. Other kids have disappeared. That's when my viewer Kevin, a tech genius From Seattle spoke up, turn on your location sharing now screenshot and send it to the chat. She did. Middle of nowhere, Utah, 40 miles from the nearest town. Kevin immediately started working magic. I'm overlaying your position with Google Earth. There's a road 800 meters northeast. Head that way. How do you know this is real? Someone challenged. The girl laughed bitterly. Google Wilderness Reformation Academy Utah. Check their reviews. Parents praising them for fixing their kids. Kids who never post anything again. After my viewer count hit 500, someone had already clipped this and it was spreading across Twitter. But we had a bigger problem. Battery at 12%, she said, and I can hear the dogs getting closer. That's when the stream chat became mission control. Sarah from Germany found an Uber driver forum for Utah. Marcus from Japan was Google Earth ing escape route. Tony from New York park was documenting everything for evidence. And Kevin. Kevin did something insane. I'm spoofing a 9 1 1 call from the camp's main building, he announced, reporting a fire in the administration office should pull their security team back. Within minutes, we heard distant sirens through her phone. The shouting changed direction. Moving away from her. The road, she gasped. I can see the road, but it was empty. Middle of the night, middle of nowhere. That's when viewer Emma from Colorado typed, my sister lives in Cedar City. That's 45 minutes away. She's getting in her car right now. The Next 20 minutes were the longest of my life. Her phone died, but not before she sent one last message. White Honda Civic, license plate starts with Q7. The stream chat stayed active all night, waiting, praying, sharing stories of their own experiences or close calls with these camps. 7:00am, Emma sister joined the discord. I have her. She's safe. We're at the police station, but they're saying the camp has legal custody. We need lawyers. Within an hour, the streaming community had rate.

People related to a psychopath, what is your creepiest story? My nephew is a crazy little person. Once the entire family was playing hide and seek. He was around 9. He didn't like where I hid, so he flew into a rage. He tried to hurt me. I grabbed his wrist and twisted just enough to subdue him. He screamed like a maniac. I released him. He then ran into another room stating he needed his Nerf gun to shoot me because he shoots people whenever he's mad. I looked at my sister in law and said, seriously? You're okay with this? Her response was that his rage was my fault, I had no right to touch him, and that I should have just let him hit me since he's only a boy. I told her quite firmly that if her crazy little kid ever even gave the appearance of causing hurt to one of my children, that I would put him down like a rabid dog. Fortunately, her husband, my wife's parents, and everyone else present told her that she was wrong, her kid was nuts, and that this was a serious red flag. Flash forward two years. Kid is still crazy, but that's everyone else's problem because he's still just a boy. I'm staying at their house. Things have mostly settled from that prior incident. I wake up very early every morning. So around 4:30 I find myself awake. I don't want to get up and wake up Everyone else. So I just sort of lie there and meditate. At around 5:20, the door opens. Thinking it's my kids, who were young at the time and still came to get us early, I kind of just glance up. Then I noticed that it's the nephew, and he's holding what appears to be an AR fifteen. Now I suffer from PTSD from Iraq, so my fight or flight response is triggered. My heart is pounding, and I'm basically in survival mode. I wait. I watch. He creeps past the foot of the bed, walks up to my side, and raises this rifle up to point the muzzle at my face. So I figure this is it. I'm going to pass away today. It ends. The only goal I have for myself right now is to prevent him from harming my wife and kids. He raises it up and the muzzle is a few inches from my face. I reached up.

Did your family realise you weren't a little kid anymore? I'm 23 and my family still cuts my food for me at restaurants. Not kidding. My mom will literally reach over and slice my chicken into bite size pieces while I'm eating it. Growing up as the youngest of seven kids by a huge gap didn't help. My siblings are all 10, 15 years older than me. So they've always treated me like they're living at family dinners. They still ask if I need help tying my shoes or if I remember to brush my teeth. My sister Amanda still tries to help me order at restaurants, telling servers she'll have the chicken nuggets without asking what I want. Last month at my cousin Abigail's wedding was the absolute worst. The whole extended family was there, aunts, uncles, grandparents, great aunts, family, friends. The worst, during cocktail hour, my Aunt Janet loudly announced that I couldn't have champagne because babies don't drink alcohol. She handed me a juice box instead. A juice box at a wedding? I'm 23 years old with a medical degree. Then came dinner seating. My uncle Mark grabbed my arm and said, come on, sweetie, you're sitting at the kids table. I tried to protest, explaining I was an adult, but he was already walking me over to a table full of actual children. Eight year olds coloring on placemats, 10 year olds playing with action figures and me with my college degree and my job. That none of them bothered asking about. The kids kept asking me questions like what grade are you in and do you like our colouring books? I spent the entire dinner helping a sick six year old nephew cut his chicken while my family laughed from the adult tables, pointing and taking photos like it was cute. My cousin Kelly walked over during appetizers. Ah, look at you helping the little ones, she cooed. Maybe someday you'll be ready for grown up conversations. She patted my head like I was a golden retriever. The breaking point came during cake cutting. When the bride and groom finished their ceremonial first slice, they started serving guests. My Uncle Mark walked over with a plate and a plastic fork. A plastic fork. Let me help you with this, honey, he said, and started cutting my slice into tiny little pieces like I was a toddler who might choke. Uncle Mark, I can careful with the fork, sweetie. He interrupted, taking it from my hands. We don't want any accidents. Remember what happened at Christmas when you tried to use the good silverware? I hadn't dropped anything at Christmas. He was just making stuff up. The entire reception was staring at this point. Other guests were whispering and pointing. Some were filming with their phones. I felt my face burning with embarrassment. That's when the bridesmaid of honour walked over. She was this elegant woman in her 40s looking confused. Excuse me, are you Doctor Nguyen, she asked, staring directly at me. Everyone at nearby tables turned to look. My Aunt Janet burst out laughing like this was the funniest thing she'd ever heard. Oh, honey, that's just our baby cousin, she said condescendingly. She's still figuring out college classes and living in the dorms, playing dress up as a doctor. Aren't you, sweetie? The woman's face went from confused to absolutely shocked. Ma'am, this is Doctor Enoguyen. She performed emergency brain surgery on my six year old daughter.
