I started having guys nights every time my wife was home. Last Friday, I left work early to surprise my wife. I had flowers and champagne. She walked in and saw me. She said, oh, you're home. Then she left to hang out with her friends. I stood there feeling stupid. This happened all the time. Every Friday she went out with friends. Every Saturday she had brunch with them. Every Sunday she went shopping. But when she was home and I tried to go anywhere, she got mad. She would yell, you never spend time with me. I bought us concert tickets. She didn't go. She went to book club instead. Her sister told me at Thanksgiving, she treats you like garbage. Tom called me while I stood there. I told him every week at my place. Thursday she texted me. She said she would stay home. Friday night, good. I invited five friends over to play poker. She came home happy. She thought we would watch movies together. She saw my friends playing cards. What the hell is this, she asked. Poker night, I said. Her face got angry fast. She ran upstairs. I smiled. Next Friday, she stayed home again. Eight friends came over to watch the game. She came downstairs in pajamas. She had popcorn. She saw all my friend. She turned around and went back upstairs. She didn't say anything. I didn't feel bad. Week 3, she took a day off work. I took the Day off too. 10 friends came over. We did our fantasy football draft. She kept walking through the room. She looked angry. Steve asked if she was okay. I said never better. Week 4 was funny. She wrote on the calendar in big red letters. It said our night, no excuses. She circled it three times. My friends came over anyway. She tried to sit with us during video games. We ignored her. She left after 12 minutes. Week 5 got bad. She made dinner reservations. She reminded me six times she bought a new dress. One hour before dinner, I texted her, forgot poker night. She called me screaming. She said I was ruining our marriage. While she yelled at me, I put her on speaker. I asked Tom to bring chips. He heard me do it. Something broke upstairs. The house shook. Week 6, she found me setting up poker tables. She started crying, please, just tonight, please. I didn't care. I told her my friends were counting on me. She said I was being mean. I said she taught me how to act this way. She said her friends were important. I said mine were too. She locked the bedroom. I slept on the couch. Next morning, six friends came for breakfast. She saw them. She took her keys and left. She went to her mom's house. Her parents anniversary party was the next day. 50 people were at the party. During speeches, she took the microphone Everyone needs to hear what's happening in my marriage, she said. Everyone got quiet. She talked for two minutes. She said I chose friends over her for six weeks. She said I played poker every night. She said I had friends over every weekend. She said I was ruining our marriage. People gasped. Her mom looked shocked. Her dad looked angry at me. My wife looked happy with herself. I stood up. I asked for the microphone. Quick question, who remembers her skipping my birthday for girls night? People raised their hands. I kept going. I talked about.

What happened when someone refused to take your life saving advice? I told a teenage girl she was gonna get assaulted working the night shift at a truck stop and she kicked me out for harassment. I've been driving trucks for 12 years now and I've seen people, men especially, at their darkest late at night on the road. I started driving trucks after my daughter was born because it paid better than warehouse work. My route takes me from Dallas up through Arkansas and into Tennessee. There's this one gas station that I try to avoid like a plague. It's one of those places where the parking lot lights are half broken and there's always sketchy stuff going down. Some nightmare on Elm Street shite. Last time I was there, some tweaker tried to sell me a chainsaw at 3 in the morning. But sometimes you need gas and it's the only stop for 40 miles. Happened about six months ago. I pulled in around 11 at night and noticed something was different right away. The old guy who usually work nights wasn't behind the counter. Instead, there was this young girl who couldn't have been older than 19. She had bright purple hair and enough piercings to make her head explode in an MRI, full sleeve, tattoos on both arms too. She was reading a textbook when I walked in so I figured she was a student. I grabbed an energy drink and some beef jerky and went Up to pay? You new here, I asked while she rang me up. Yeah, started last week, she said, without looking up from scanning. They had a help wanted sign in the hours. Work with my class schedule. Well, my stomach dropped a little. This girl had no idea what she'd signed up for. So I told her very respectfully, listen, I don't mean to pry, but you might want to find somewhere else to work. This place gets rough, especially at night. She finally looked up at me and her face went hard. I can take care of myself, thanks. That annoyed me a little, but I needed her to understand. I'm sure you can, but the drivers that come through here aren't your average customers. Some of these guys have been on the road for days straight. They get weird ideas in their heads, especially when they see a young woman working alone. Is that supposed to be a threat? Her voice got sharp. No, I'm trying to warn you. I've been stopping here for years and I've seen some bad stuff go down. You need to at least keep some heat under the counter for Protection. Get out. She pointed at the door. I don't need some random trucker man explaining danger to me. I that I can handle myself. I don't even know what mansplaining is. I said, look, I have a daughter about your age and I'd want someone to tell her before I could Even say anything else, she screamed out, before I call the cops and report you for harassment, I held up my hands and backed away. Fine, I tried. Some people just won't listen when you're trying to help them. I paid for my stuff and left without another word. Back in my truck, I popped open the energy drink and did my usual safety check. Tires looked good. Load was cure. I was just about to pull out when I remembered I'd promised my wife I'd grab diapers on the way home. My wife just had another baby girl. She goes through them like crazy and we were almost out. I sat there for a minute debating whether to go back in. The girl clearly didn't want me there, but I really needed those diapers. I waited about five minutes to let things cool down, then headed back inside. The store was empty. That purple haired girl behind the counter, I hoped for the best and told myself maybe she was in the bathroom or on break. Then I heard.

What's the most insane reason someone demanded you quit your dream? My fiance, Annie threw her engagement ring at my face, screaming, drop out of medical school or we're done. I won't marry someone who stares at spread legs and female organs all day pretending it's for education Act 1. The accusation knocked the wind out of me. Years together. We'd sworn we'd be doctors together. Save lives side by side. Except I just started at the third best medical school in America with a partial scholarship while Annie folded shirts at target after getting rejected from everywhere, including our joke safety school. Friday night shattered everything. I was highlighting nerve pathways when she came home from work. She kissed my temple and then froze. Her face transformed from exhaustion to rage. What the hell is this? She jabbed at my anatomy textbook, specifically the reproductive system chapter. Anatomy homework, I said, genuinely confused. Don't play innocent. These detailed drawings of lady parts. It's disgusting, Annie. It's required course work. Required? She laughed, sharp and bitter. Required to stare at this filth. She snatched my four hundred dollar textbook and disappeared into our bedroom. The lock clicked. Muffled sobs, then silence. The door cracked open just wide enough for her engagement ring to sail past my ear. Choose, she said through the gap. This perverted career or me. Saturday morning brought an empty apartment and a text. Staying with Melissa. You have one week to withdraw from school and find Respectable work. Otherwise, return my stuff to my aunt's house. The threat felt surreal. This was the woman who celebrated my acceptance letter with champagne she couldn't afford. Act 2. I took my anatomy exam Monday. 94%. When I texted Annie the score, hoping normals he might return, she responded instantly. So you're choosing to continue violating women with your eyes? Noted. Melissa called an hour later. You're disgusting. Annie told me about your sick obsession. Melissa, I study medicine. These are medical illustrations. She found your browser history. All those medical sites with naked bodies. That Pub Med. It's a research database. Whatever helps you sleep creep. The line went dead. Tuesday, I returned from gross anatomy lab to find our apartment gutted of Annie's belongings. A sticky note on the refrigerator read, Final Chance. Withdraw by Friday. Where I tell everyone why we really broke up. I called my advisor, Doctor Collins, who guided me through applications. She listened as I explained my personal situation. You're one of three students from your state to ever enter our program, she said. Whatever's happening, remember why you're here. Act 3, Thursday was when things got ugly. Annie posted on social media about just finding out I've been dating a. And how disgusted and violated she felt. My phone exploded with concerned texts. My mother called three times, her voicemails increasingly frantic about what her future daughter in law could possibly mean. That evening, Annie called. Her voice was eerily calm. Like she rehearsed this conversation. Have you withdrawn yet? I gripped the phone tighter. No. This is insane, Annie. You know what's insane? My boyfriend getting off on medical diagrams while I work minimum wage. Before I could respond, she continued her words, picking up speed. I emailed your dean, told him about your unhealthy obsession with female anatomy, how you spend hours staring at those pages. You did what? I also contacted the medical board, asked if students with clear sexual fixation should be allowed near patients. Said they investigate. Annie, you're going to destroy my career before it even starts. This is me protecting future patients from you. She hung up, then texted screenshots of emails she drafted to my professors, each one more damaging than the last. Act 4 Sunday, I drove to Melissa's apartment, determined that

What broke your heart and restored your faith in humanity at the same time? A 13 year old offered me his entire savings just to come to his birthday party, saying you don't have to bring a present or anything. No one else is going anyway. He shoved a piece of paper at me and started backing away. It was a handmade invitation with crayon borders and his name written carefully in the middle, Joshua turning 13. I ruffled up his hair and smiled. I'll be there, kid. His eyes lit up and his lips formed the biggest grin. It's on Saturday. I'll save you some cake, he shouted before running off excitedly towards his parents in one of the grocery aisles yelling, I got one, I got one. I looked back at the invitation in my hand feeling my heartbreak, remembering him say no one else is going. After work. I drove by Joshua's address that night and saw one sad balloon tied to the mailbox and I knew I couldn't just leave things like this. I mentioned the party to my family over dinner and they all got the Joshua look on their faces. We're going, my sister said immediately. Even my parents nodded. I texted a few friends too. That's when things got out of hand. My friend posted in our town Facebook group while I was asleep, this kid is turning 13 on Saturday and literally no one is coming to his party. Anyone free 2 To 4, I woke up to my phone buzzing non stop. Someone had made a group chat called Joshua's Birthday Squad and it already had 47 people already excited for the surprise. Surprise. My daughter's using her allowance to buy him a present. Who's bringing balloons? I'll get the cake. Even the local pizza place owner was there offering 10 free boxes on the house. school football team was arguing about who got to carry in the cake and a retired magician offered to give the best show in town. People were tagging their friends, their neighbors, their co workers. Get everyone, someone wrote. I sat there staring at my phone when already grinning just thinking about little Joshua's reaction. I told the group, everyone meet at the park at 2:15. We'll walk over together. When I got to the park, I couldn't believe it. Nearly 50 people were there with presents, balloons and the pizza guy had a tower of boxes. Ready, guys, they nodded. I texted the number on Joshua's invitation.

How did you trick your entire high school? Our cafeteria had this weird echo problem in the back corner where the ceiling tiles were loose. If you whispered there during lunch, it would amplify and carry across the entire room like a ghost voice. I discovered this by accident when I was hiding back there, eating alone, complaining under my breath about Mr Rodriguez's impossible math test. Suddenly, half the cafeteria turned around looking confused. That's when the idea hit me. I started small, whispering random stuff during lunch to test the range. Someone left their car lights on or free pizza in the gym, just enough to watch heads turn and people look around confused. The acoustics were perfect. My voice would bounce off the loose tiles, get amplified by the weird ceiling cavity, then float across the room like some supernatural announcement. It sounded nothing like my normal voice, more like a distant radio transmission or a voice from another dimension. But then I overheard the drama that would change everything. Jessica Chen was bragging to her friends about how she'd been anonymously reporting kids to administration for vaping. I've gotten like 12 people suspended, he laughed. They have no idea it's me. I just sent anonymous tips to Principal Walsh's email. She was proud of it, genuinely proud of ruining people's lives for a few extra points on her college applications. Perfect. Target acquired. The next day during lunch, I positioned myself in the Echo corner. I Waited until Jessica was surrounded by her usual crowd, then whispered just loud enough. Jessica Chen is the vaping snitch, the whisper.

He told me 6, 7. So I fucked his grandpa. Now, before you call me crazy, stay right there or I'll suck your balls one by one. A simple joke. A meme repeated a thousand times by fucking kids on the internet. But when he threw it in my face, I felt a crack open inside me. As if behind that laughter there was icy contempt. A refusal to take me seriously. He thought I'd laugh with him, but hell nah. So I chose to tear away from him what he thought was untouchable. His grandfather. The old man was guilty of nothing except existing in his lineage. And having this little bastard with him. His wrinkled skin, his fragile breath. He embodied innocence. And that's precisely what made my act more cruel. I took it. I destroyed it piece by piece, until only a suffocating silence remained. And then the unthinkable happened. Like a curse born of my actions, his body began to swell. To swell with an alien life. The grandfather, despite his age, now carried within him an impossible pregnancy. An abomination. A cursed child conceived in pain and despair. When his grandson discovered what was happening, his eyes filled with horror. I looked him straight in the eyes and whispered, did you wanna laugh? Look. Now your grandfather carries within him the proof of my vengeance. And that laughter will haunt you until your death. That day, he understood that some jokes are worth more than A smile. They breed monsters

Nine year old daughter pulled the emergency break on our school bus during a field trip and she saved 40 kids from dying. The piercing screech of the emergency break cut through the happy chatter of 40 fourth graders as our school bus lurched to a violent stop on Highway 15. My daughter, Sophia had yanked the red emergency handle with both hands, sending kids flying forward in their seats. The bus driver, Mister Rodriguez, fought to control the skidding vehicle. Backpacks and lunch boxes went flying as the bus finally stopped just 150 feet before the Millbrook Bridge. What is wrong with you? Mister Rodriguez shouted, turning around to glare at Sophia, who was still gripping the emergency brake handle. You could have killed everyone on this bus! The other kids were crying and yelling at Sophia for scaring them, while the parent chaperone demanded to know why she'd pull such a dangerous stunt during their field trip to the Natural History Museum. Sophia stood up in the aisle, tears streaming down her face, and pointed toward the bridge ahead of us. The bridge is going to collapse, she said in this shaky voice. I saw it happen in my dream last night. The middle part falls into the water and everyone drowns. Mr. Rodriguez rolled his eyes and several parents started muttering about Sophia being a troubled child who needed professional help. But then Sophia pulled out her sketchbook where she'd been frantically drawing during the bus ride. Page after page show detailed sketches of our yellow school bus plunging through a collapsed bridge, with stick figures of her classmates trapped underwater. She'd drawn the exact bridge we were approaching, complete with the distinctive blue steel arches and the Milbrook crossing established 1959 plaque that was visible from where we'd stopped. Sophia, honey, that's just a bad dream, said Missus Walsh, one of the parent volunteers. Bridges don't just fall down, especially not ones that have been standing for for 60 years. But Sophia shook her head violently and opened her sketchbook to another page, where she'd written down specific details about what she'd seen in her nightmare. The pages showed time stamps and sequence of events. 11:23 a m, bus drives onto bridge. 11:00am loud cracking sound from support cables. 11:00am center section drops. 11:00am bus falls into River. Sophia had written these notes at 2:00am, according to the time stamp on her phone, hours before we'd even left for the field trip. Rodriguez was already radioing the school to report Sophia's behavior when we heard the first deep groaning sound coming from the direction of

I pulled away from my identical twin sister, even though I know it has caused her to spiral. I'm Casey and my twin sister is Katie. Yeah, our parents really thought they were being cute with those names. They did everything possible to make sure we were basically the same person our entire lives. We shared a bed until I was 18, not just a room, the same bed. Every night, Katie would wrap her arms around me like I was her teddy bear and I'd lie there awake, wanting to scream. When I tried to sleep on the floor, she'd cry until her parents made me get back in bed with her. School was a nightmare. Our parents demanded we be in every single class together, same desk, partner for group projects, same lunch table, same everything. Teachers would literally call us the twins instead of our actual names. Katie loved it. She'd introduce us by saying we're Katie and Casey and answer questions meant for me, the worst part was friends. Someone invited me to hang out, Katie automatically assumed she was invited, too. She'd show up wherever I was supposed to meet people. This girl, Emma, from my chemistry class asked me to study together once and Katie just appeared at the library with all her books. Emma never asked me to study again. When I was 14, I got really sick with some stomach thing and had to stay in the hospital for two nights. Katie Had a complete meltdown because she couldn't stay with me. She sat in the parking lot crying for hours until security made our parents take her home. Those two nights alone were the first time I'd slept peacefully in years. No, no one breathing in my face or stealing my blankets or asking me what I was thinking about every five minutes. I started planning my escape. Junior year, Katie thought we were going to the same college and being roommates forever. Our parents had already called the admissions office trying to make sure we'd be placed together. I applied to different schools without telling anyone. I got into this community college three states away, saved up money from my part time job at the grocery store. The day after graduation, I told them I wasn't going to college. Katie freaked out, asking what we were going to do instead. Not what I was going to do, what we were going to do. That's when I knew I had to get out immediately. I packed my stuff while they were at dinner, just threw everything into trash bags and left. My friend Jess let me crash at her place for two weeks. Then we both moved to start college together. I blocked everyone's numbers and social media for 3 months. I had peace. I could eat what I wanted for breakfast. I could watch whatever show I liked. I could make friends without someone else inserting themselves into every conversation. It was amazing, but I felt guilty. So I unblocked Katie's number. Big mistake. She'd been calling and texting non stop for months. Hundreds of messages, some angry, some sad, some just saying she missed me. She'd already dropped out of college after one semester. She told me she couldn't focus on anything without me there. She couldn't sleep. She couldn't make friends because she kept talking about her missing twin sister. Our parents.

I found out why my husband always volunteers for night shifts at the hospital. For two years, I thought Kevin was just really dedicated to his job. He'd come home at 7:00am looking exhausted, shower, then sleep until three PM. He always said the night shift paid better and there was less drama with the doctors. Made perfect sense to me. He's a respiratory therapist and I know those jobs are tough. Every Thursday night he'd pack his little lunch bag with those terrible gas station sandwiches he loves, grab his coffee thermos, and kiss me goodbye. See you in the morning, babe, he'd say, and I'd already be half asleep. Sometimes I'd wake up around 2:00am and text him cute messages like hope your shift isn't too crazy with heart emojis. He always replied right away, which I thought was sweet. Last Tuesday, I had food poisoning from some sketchy sushi and felt absolutely terrible. Kevin had already left for work, but around midnight I was throwing up so badly I thought I might need to go to the ER. I called the hospital main line and asked them to page Kevin in respiratory therapy. The night operator put me on hold for like 10 minutes. When she came back, she sounded confused. Ma'am, we don't have anyone named Kevin scheduled in respiratory tonight. Are you sure you have the right department? I told her his last name, described him, everything. She checked again. No Kevin working anywhere in The hospital. That night my stomach dropped and it wasn't from the food poisoning anymore. I hung up and immediately called Kevin cell. It went straight to voicemail. I called three more times. Nothing. I threw on clothes and drove to the hospital parking garage where Kevin always parked his beat up Honda. It wasn't there. At this point I'm starting to panic and coming up with all sorts of crazy explanations. Maybe he got transferred to a different hospital. Maybe there was some emergency. I drove around for two hours checking other hospitals nearby. Nothing. Finally went home and waited until 7:00am when he usually got back right on schedule. I heard his car in the driveway. He walked in looking tired as all.
NA

What childhood experience still controls you today? My mom had this thing called trust falls, but not the normal kind where you fall backward into someone's arms. Every few weeks she'd randomly yell trust fall and pretend to faint. Didn't matter where we were, kitchen, grocery store, parking lot, she'd just drop. The rule was we had to catch her before she hit the ground. My brother and I got really good at this, developed a whole system. I'd grab shoulders, he'd grab legs. We could catch her mid collapse from across the room. Our reflexes were insane. If we missed, she'd lie there perfectly still until we started crying and begging her to wake up. Then she'd pop up laughing, you need to be faster. What if this was real? I thought every family did this, like a fire drill, but for medical emergencies. I'd brag to friends about our response time. 1.3 seconds was our record. Kids at school thought it was badass that we were basically training to be paramedics. Teachers were impressed by our emergency preparedness. I even put it on my college applications under special skills. The game evolved as we got older. Sometimes she'd clutch her chest first. Sometimes she'd add choking sounds. Once she fell down half a flight of stairs, we caught her before she hit the landing. She was so proud. When I was 22, I was at my boyfriend's family dinner when his grandma stood up too fast and got Dizzy. Before anyone could blink, I'd launched across the table, knocking over dishes and caught her midwobble. The whole family stared at me like I was insane. I was crouched there supporting this confused elderly woman, gravy dripping down my shirt, ready to administer CPR. My boyfriend's mom gently helped me let go of grandma, who was fine, just needed to sit down, and asked if I was okay. I explained about our trust falls training and the silence was deafening. That's when my boyfriend said what everyone was thinking. Your mom pretended to die to test if you'd save her. Well, when you put it like that, turns out mom has severe thanatophobia, fear of death. The trust falls weren't training us. They were her way of controlling her panic attacks. If she knew we'd catch her, she felt less scared about randomly dying. She'd been using us as emotional support animals since we were kids. My brother ended up becoming an EMT. He says he can't help the adrenaline rush when anyone stumbles. His partner thinks he's heroic. Really, he's just traumatized. I can't relax in public ever. Part of my brain is always scanning for falling people. I've caught three strangers in the past year. They think I'm some kind of guardian angel. Nope, just programmed to prevent any human from hitting the ground. The worst part, when I confronted mom about it, she said, but look how prepared you are. You could save someone's life. Yeah. I could, but I can't eat dinner without mapping exit routes and catch positions for every person in the restaurant. Last month, my therapist asked me to show her what I meant. I had her sit in different positions around the room while I demonstrated my catch approach for each angle. She watched me calculate trajectory and response time for 15 minutes before quietly saying, this isn't normal emergency preparedness. This is hyper vigilance. But hey, if you ever need someone to catch you, I'm your girl. 1.3 seconds. That's still my record.
NA

When did you accidentally expose someone's biggest lie? I was in 8th grade when Kyle, the new kids started passing out these fancy birthday invitations. They had gold glitter and said VIP guest in big letters. Kyle was always bragging about how his dad owned 5 restaurants and his mom was a model. He said they lived in this huge mansion with a pool that had a diving board and a water slide. Everyone in class was losing their minds over this party. Kyle made it sound like it was gonna be the event of the year. He handed me an invite, too. Even though we barely talked, I felt pretty special since all the popular kids were going. The invitation said Saturday at three PM Kyle had written the address by hand in messy letters. I'd never been to that part of town before, but my mom agreed to drive me even though she was working crazy overtime that week. We pulled up to the address right on time, but something was totally wrong. There were no decorations, no balloons, no cars parked outside, just this regular old house that looked kind of run down. The lawn needed cutting and the paint was peeling. My mom double checked the address. Are you sure this is right, Jordan? I pulled out the glittery invitation. Same street name, same house number. This had to be it. I walked up and rang the doorbell. This older woman answered looking confused as heck She had gray hair and was wearing a bathrobe. Can I help you, she asked. Um, hi, I'm here for Kyle's birthday party. He invited me. The woman just stared at me. Kyle? I don't know any Kyle, sweetie. My stomach dropped to my feet. My mom stepped up behind me and asked again, thinking maybe the woman misheard. But she shook her head and said no party was happening at her house. No Kyle live there either. I felt my face get hot with embarrassment. We apologized and walked back to the car. I.

Guys, I think my dad is a fucking femboy and my mom is into that shit. Don't get me wrong, I love the man. But I've been noticing some weird ass behavior lately. So it's Monday morning. I wake up late as fuck, already annoyed because school exists, right? I'm rushing to get my shit together. I somehow located both my goddamn missing socks and I step out of my room only to hear some high pitched voice coming from my dad's office. Naturally being a curious idiot, I go check. Worst decision of my life. My dad is on all fours barking at my mother dressed in a fucking maid outfit it with cat ears. I'm talking full on submissive mode. My mom is standing over him like a goddamn dominatrix holding a whip, a fucking whip. And then as if I'm the one in the wrong, their eyes go wide and my mom has the audacity to yell, get out and close the damn door, lady. You just.

I told my sister in law that I've had four miscarriages when she said I didn't understand her loss. My sister in law Kelly had her first miscarriage about six months ago. It was devastating. I get that. The whole family rallied around her and my brother Jake, bringing casseroles and giving them space to. But then she started acting like she was the only person who'd ever lost a baby. It started small. At family dinners, she'd make comments about how nobody understood what real loss felt like. When my cousin Amanda talked about her dog dying, Kelly rolled her eyes and said that's not the same thing at all. When my mom mentioned missing my grandpa who died last year, Kelly literally scoffed and said, you got to say goodbye to him. Though the worst part was how she treated me. I've been married to my husband Chris for 8 years and we don't have kids yet. Kelly started making these passive aggressive comments about how lucky I was to not have to worry about these things, how I couldn't possibly understand what she was going through. Last weekend was my nephew's birthday party. Kelly seemed okay during most of it, playing with the kids and laughing at their jokes. But then my brother's friend brought up how his wife was pregnant and Kelly's whole mood shifted. She got quiet and started picking out her food. Later when we were in the kitchen cleaning up, Kelly started talking. About how hard it was seeing pregnant women everywhere. I tried to be supportive, telling her I understood how triggering that must be. That's when she snapped. No, you don't understand, she said, her voice getting louder. You have no idea what it's like to lose a baby. You've never even been pregnant. You don't know what real loss feels like. Something inside me just broke. I've been holding this in for years, keeping it private because Chris and I decided we didn't want the whole family knowing our business. But I was so tired of her acting like she had a monopoly on grief. Actually, Kelly, I said, my voice shaking, I've had four miscarriages. The kitchen went dead silent. My mom dropped the plate she was holding. Kelly's face went completely white. The first one was three years ago. I can continued. I was 12 weeks along. We thought we were safe to tell people, but then I started bleeding at work. Chris had to pick me up from the bathroom floor. Kelly tried to say something, but I kept going. The second one was a year later. Only eight weeks that time, but it didn't hurt any less. The third one was right before Christmas Last year. I spent New Year's Eve in the hospital. The fourth one was two months ago.

My boyfriend keeps laughing with my female co worker and teaching her his language. She still thinks she's learning how to flirt. Trish started working at my waitressing job five months ago and from the moment she saw my boyfriend Kyle, she set her eyes on him like he was the last Infinity Stone. He was half Japanese like me, meaning we related on a deep level. And for some reason, Trish hated this most. First time she saw us having lunch, she made herself comfortable in my seat next to his. When I got up to use the bathroom, she pressed her hips against his and flashed a flirty smile before saying konnichiwa. When he awkwardly said it back, she grabbed a pair of chopsticks and started eating noodles unsuccessfully complaining about whitewashed girls appropriating his beautiful culture, very obviously referring to me. When I came back in the bathroom, she told me to grab a chair, telling me I was welcome to join in on their conversation. It definitely struck a nerve but I was so secure here and Kaido and I's relationship, I didn't even mind until Trish started trying to implode us. She cornered him when I wasn't looking and tell him innuendo style phrases in Japanese that she got off Google translate. Whenever we were talking, she'd always squeeze past us very slowly, sometimes making sure to rub her behind against Kaido and other times facing him directly and giving him the effing eyes, the Thing that really made me mad was when she asked Kaido to come teach her Japanese at her house after work. I was going to confront her there and then, but we were in the middle of a very busy service and I told myself I'd do it right after. Big mistake. You see, at some point during service, these important Japanese businessmen came in for food. They were at my section, but Trish practically shoved me aside to serve them. Please speak Japanese. I understand everything, she told them. They looked pleasantly surprised and started rattling off their order with specific modifications and allergies. Trish just kept saying, hi, hi, while scribbling nonsense. 45 minutes later, it was chaos. One guy got served the wrong starter. Another received two sushi orders instead of his chicken chow Mein. And the third guy actually started having an allergic reaction to shellfish, which he asked to exclude. That's when Trish did it. While Kaido ran to get the Epipen, she pointed at me and told her cousin, who is the manager, that I changed the order to sabotage her. And without verifying anything, her cousin wrote me up on the spot in front of everyone. One more incident and you're terminated. I went home crushed and just cried to Kaido. I was wondering.

At my nephew's birthday, I said, can't wait for the family dinner tomorrow. My cousin laughed. Wait, that was yesterday. My aunt showed photos, everyone smiling. My sister muttered, maybe take the hint. I stayed silent. But what I did next wiped their smiles. I should have known something was wrong the second my cousin laughed. It was the night after my nephew Liam's 7th birthday. I'd stayed late rinsing plates, still buzzing from the way his face lit up when I gave him the Lego set he begged for. For once, I felt included. So I said it without thinking. Can't wait for the big family dinner tomorrow. Tara froze, then burst out laughing. Wait, you don't know that was yesterday. My stomach dropped. My aunt casually pulled out her phone, swiping through photos, a long table with fairy lights, champagne toasts, speeches, the annual reunion dinner, the one my mom always hosted, the one I've been at every year, and somehow I wasn't there. Oh, this is right before dessert, my aunt said. That's when your mom gave her speech about being surrounded by all her blessings. Her words shattered me. I turned to my sister. She didn't look up from the dish towel. Maybe take the hint next time, she muttered. Silence. My throat locked. I set the sponge down, picked up Liam's birthday card, stuffed with a gift card, and slipped out the door. On the drive home, her words echoed, a hint, not cruel, not Angry just fact like I've been stupid to keep showing up. That night, I replayed every forgotten invite, every missing group chat, every photo I wasn't in. It wasn't mistakes. It was policy. I wasn't family. Fine then. They could live without me. For years, I've been funding everything behind the scenes. College savings for me as kid, emergency dental work, Mom's roof repairs, all hidden as anonymous grants from my LLC. I never asked for credit, just wanted to help. The morning after, mom called in a panic, AC's out 8 grand. The guy you usually work with said the fund didn't come through. Did something happen? I dissolved the program. I said flatly, I'm sure everyone who was at the dinner can figure something out. I hung up. Within a week, every fund I'd set up was frozen. The safety net was gone. Two weeks later, my inbox filled with frantic voicemails. I ignored them. Then I remembered I still had admin rights to the family group chat, the one I'd created years ago. The same chat I hadn't been added to in months. I renamed it. Maybe take the hint. Then I removed every single member. No explanation, just silence. But the lighthouse was the crown jewel. Legally, I owned half. Mom sold me her share years ago. They still treated it like communal property. Some summer's reunions, weekends, I never blocked them. I even paid for the DOC last year. Not anymore. Memorial Day, their biggest. Tradition. I filed a partition clause restricting access unless new agreements were signed. Of course, Tara hadn't opened her mail, so Friday, I parked my truck across the driveway and waited. By noon, three cars rolled up, my sister, my mom, Tara, kids tumbling out with floaties. Laughter died when they saw me. You're here.

The longest menstrual cycle you've ever had. I was sitting on my boyfriend's lap when my coochie started bleeding. Silas helped me put a tampon in, but I soaked through it in just 20 minutes. We rushed to the ER, and when I bled through the examination table paper three times, they insisted on keeping me overnight. The hematologist actually said this shouldn't be possible, while I just sat there shaking. The ride home was silent for my apologies every time we hit a bump and I felt another gush. For two weeks, he kept making me these protein smoothies every morning, packed with iron for the blood loss. But the bleeding somehow got worse, and I was soaking through overnight pads in 30 minutes. When I mentioned this to Silas, he got defensive and said I was being ungrateful. His voice had this edge that made me shut up immediately. By day 23, I was going through a box of super tampons every two days. Silas had started this weird notebook, writing down time stamps and low levels. And when I asked what it was for, he said, documentation in this flat voice that made my skin crawl. I'd catch him staring at me sometimes with this expression I couldn't read, like he was waiting for something. My mom stopped inviting me over after I bled through her couch, and the way she looked at me like I was diseased still makes me want to cry. The gynecologist prescribed Birth control pills to stop the bleeding, but they made it 10 times worse. And when I called Silas, crying from the bathroom floor, he seemed almost excited, asking about the color and consistency. That's when Relina, his ex girlfriend, messaged me on Instagram. My hands were trembling as I read. We need to talk about Silas. It's about your bleeding. We met at a coffee shop, where she pulled up medical records on her phone showing she'd had unexplained bleeding for two months. It started right after.

What crazy gut feeling turned out to actually be true? It was Monday morning in math class when my teacher asked for the homework, and mine was nowhere to be found. I was confused. I remember doing it, stuffing it in my binder, and even double checking it before class, but somehow it was gone. I figured maybe I misplaced it. No big deal. Until two days later, same thing, another assignment, and again it was missing. Now I knew something was up. Homework doesn't just vanish twice in one week. I started thinking, who would even want my homework? And that's when I noticed something weird. Every time I'd hang out with my friend before class, he'd always offer to hold my stuff for me if I left the room. Like, why would anyone volunteer to babysit my backpack? The next day, I decided to test my theory. I left my backpack unattended for just a minute while I went to the bathroom. But really, I peeked through the window, and there he was, unzipping my backpack like it was his. When I walked back in, he jumped like he'd seen a ghost. Oh, uh, I was just fixing your zipper. Yeah, right. At that point, my gut feeling was screaming at me. I knew he was the one taking my homework. So when he left the room later that day, I opened his binder, and there it was. Both of my missing assignments with my name erased. And His name written over them. He wasn't just stealing my homework. I was literally customizing it. I was furious. So I did the only logical thing. I snitched. I handed everything to the teacher. And when my friend came back, the look on his face was priceless. He tried to deny it, but the teacher just stared him down and said, so you both just happened to do the exact same homework with the exact same handwriting? He ended up getting detention for two weeks. And me, the teacher gave me a homework pass for the entire month. The funniest part? When I got home, he texted me asking if he could borrow my homework again.

Bought my mom a house and paid all the bills for three years straight. Then at a family dinner, she looked me in the eyes and said, you give us nothing but headaches. The room went dead silent. My uncle stopped chewing mid bite, a piece of roast beef hanging from his fork. My aunt stared at her plate like it held the secrets of the universe. My cousins suddenly found their phones fascinating, frantically scrolling through TikTok to avoid the tension. Not one person defended me. I had covered everything for three years. The 12 thousand eight hundred dollar monthly mortgage on this 4 bedroom house in the suburbs. Water, electricity, gas, internet. The premium package because my teenage cousins needed their Netflix and gaming. Groceries every week, sometimes twice when they had friends over. Car insurance for both vehicles in the driveway, even the landscaping service because mom complained about the neighbors judging her lawn. Every month, without fail, 4 two hundred dollars left my account to keep their lives comfortable while I lived in a studio apartment across town, eating ramen and skipping vacations. That's not fair, mom! I said, my voice steady despite my hands shaking under the table. I literally pay for everything here. This house, the food you're eating, the lights above our heads, and you never let us forget it! She snapped, her voice rising. You act like some hero swooping in to save us, but real family doesn't keep school for real. Family helps without making everyone feel guilty about it. Real family. I looked around the table at these people I've been supporting. My brother Julian shifted uncomfortably in his chair, suddenly very interested in cutting his steak into perfect squares. My sister in law, Nora, studied her wine glass like she was conducting a chemistry experiment. My uncle cleared his throat and reached for assault. He didn't need complete, deafening silence. You know what hurts the most? I continued, my voice getting stronger. It's not just the money. It's that I rearranged my entire life for you. I turned down a promotion that required relocating because you said you needed me close. I broke up with Layla because you said she was taking too much of my attention away from family. Mom waved her hand dismissively. Oh, please don't blame us for your failed relationships. I did it. Something inside me snapped like a dry twig. Okay, I said, standing up so abruptly my chair scraped against the hardwood floor. Okay what? Mom frowned, finally looking uncertain. If my help is such a burden, if I'm such a guilt tripping burden to this family, then I won't burden you anymore. I walked to the coat closet, grabbed my jacket, and headed for the door. Behind me I could hear nervous whispers starting up, but no one called my name. No one asked me to stay that night. I sat in my car in the parking lot of my apartment complex. And grabbed my phone. One by one, I canceled every automatic payment connect did to her accounts. The mortgage payment scheduled for next week. Canceled the utility auto pay that had been running for three years straight. Canceled the grocery store credit card I'd added her as an authorized user on. Canceled the car insurance, the internet Bill, even the stupid premium lawn care service. All of it gone with a few taps on my screen. Three days later, my phone rang at 6:00am. Mom's name flashed on the

Adorable nickname your family gave you did you later realise had a completely different meaning? My Japanese grandmother called me Bakachan from the day I was born. I thought it meant little treasure or precious jewel in Japanese. She would pat my head and say Bakachan with such warmth in her voice. I felt like the most special grandchild in the world when she said it. In fourth grade, I did a family tree project explaining how Bakachan was a sacred Japanese term. It showed how much my grandmother cherished me above all her other grandchildren. My teacher, who I now realise spoke Japanese, kept making strangled noises and spilling her coffee. I thought she was just emotional about my beautiful cultural presentation. I begged my parents for a Bakugan themed birthday party. We had custom napkins printed with akachan Sweet 16 in Japanese characters. The Japanese bakery tried to refuse our order three times. They kept suggesting alternatives, like birthday girl or literally anything else. My mom had to pay triple to convince them. For my 18th birthday, I got bakuchan tattooed on my wrist in beautiful Japanese characters. The tattoo artist, clearly Japanese, made me sign five different waivers. He kept muttering in Japanese and showing me pictures of butterflies and cherry blossoms. Instead, I insisted on bakuchan because I wanted authenticity. He took photos of the consent forms while shaking his head. My college application essay centered around being called bakuchan and what it meant to me. I wrote about how this precious nick connected me to my Japanese heritage. I explained how it represented unconditional love and acceptance in Japanese culture. I got into several schools and was convinced my touching essay made the difference. Freshman year, I decorated my dorm room with a giant neon sign saying Bakachan's Palace in Japanese. My Korean roommate took one look and immediately requested a room transfer. When I explained the beautiful meaning, she just patted my shoulder sadly and doubled her transfer request. I assumed she was intimidated by my cultural authenticity. I joined the Asian Student Union and introduced myself as Bakachan at every event. The Japanese exchange students would freeze and then whisper frantically to each other. One girl actually laughed out loud before her friend elbowed her hard. I thought they were impressed by how connected I was to Japanese traditions. My boyfriend got property of Bakugan printed on a hoodie for Valentine's Day. His Japanese roommate saw it and laughed so hard he needed his inhaler. When my boyfriend wore it to the International Student Mixer, the entire Japanese Student Association took group photos with him. I thought they were admiring our cross cultural romance. Junior year, I finally got to study broad in Tokyo. At customs, I proudly declared Watashi WA bakachan desu. The officer dropped his stamp and called his supervisor over. They had a heated discussion in rapid Japanese while staring at my passport. I assumed they were impressed by my perfect Pronunciation I made friends with a girl who seemed constantly on the edge of telling me something. She'd start sentences, then stop herself and shake her head. One day she asked
NA
NA

In our divorce hearing, my wife smirked. I'm taking 70% of your millions including your dad's estate. The courtroom erupted until I stood, handed the judge a two page document and said, check again. Judge simply looked at my wife and burst out laughing. My name is James and three months ago I caught my wife Lauren cheating with her yoga instructor. He filed for divorce immediately thinking she'd hit the Jackpot. Since we've been married for five years, Lauren strutted into that Phoenix courtroom wearing a two thousand dollar dress I'd bought her, confident as hell her lawyer was already calculating his commission on what they thought would be a four million dollar payout for my construction business and dad's inheritance. The whole courtroom was packed. Lauren had actually invited some of her friends to watch what she called James's comeuppance. He'd been telling everyone for weeks how she was about to become independently wealthy. Your honor, her attorney announced, adjusting his expensive tie. Mrs. Peterson deserves substantial compensation for supporting her husband's career growth during their five year marriage. Lauren actually winked at me from across the room. She thought I was just some heartbroken guy who'd roll over and pay whatever she demanded. Her friends in the gallery were practically grinning waiting for the show. But here's what Lauren didn't know. Six months before I caught her cheating, I'd started noticing weird charges on our joint credit card, expensive dinners at restaurants I'd never been to, hotel Rooms booked during girls trips that didn't add up, designer lingerie purchases that never made it home. The final straw was when I found a 800 dollar charge at a jewelry store downtown. When I asked Lauren.

When did your teacher give everyone a free A+? Mrs. Lambert walked into class with tears streaming down her face and slammed her coffee mug on the desk so hard it broke. If one of you can find the woman my husband is cheating on me with, I will give you an A+ for the semester and you can stop doing work. Just please help me catch her so I can deliver justice. Someone in the back raised their hand slowly and asked if that was really all they had to do. Missus Lambert nodded and laid out three rules. 1, we couldn't get caught snooping around. 2, we couldn't break into anyone's homes. 3, we could work in teams if we wanted. The bell rang right after, and my best friend Kenji grabbed my arm and pulled me into the hallway. He said, I got a plan. This will be easy money. Trust me. Missus Lambert's husband was Coach Lambert, who taught Jim and coached girls volleyball. Kenji figured he was probably sleeping with one of the volleyball players since he spent so much time with them after school. We decided to start our investigation that afternoon during volleyball practice. We sucked into the gym and hid behind the bleachers with a clear view of the court, Coach Lambert was running drills and yelling at the girls to hustle. He seemed normal at first, but then we noticed he kept touching the team captain's shoulder when explaining plays. The Practice went on for an hour and nothing suspicious happened. We were about to give up when Coach Lambert called the captain Abriel into his office. He jogged over, bouncing her ponytail and followed him inside. Through the window, we could see her tying her hair up in a bun while he made sure no one was looking, then turned off the lights and pulled down the blinds, blocking our view completely. Kenji and I looked at each other, knowing she was giving him the gawk, gawk 3,000. He quietly left the gym and started heading back to Mrs. Lambert's classroom to claim our a plus. We were practically running down the hallway when we heard footsteps behind us. Two kids from our class tackled us to the ground before we could react. They and us down while their teammate Jasmine sprinted ahead toward Missus Lambert's room. We struggled, but they were bigger and had caught us off guard. By the time we got free and made it to the classroom, Jasmine was already inside talking to the teacher. After Jasmine left, looking smug, I went into the classroom alone. Missus Lambert was sitting at her desk, crying harder than before. I told her what we'd seen with Coach Lambert and April in his office. She, she thanked me through her tears and said she suspected the volleyball team all along. But then I realized something off. I asked her, are you okay? Like actually okay. Missus Lambert looked up. At me with surprise. She actually smiled a little through her tears and said I was the first student to ask how she was feeling. I apologized for not asking sooner and told her that even though she was a tough teacher, she didn't deserve to be cheated on. She stood up and walked around her desk. Do you still want that a plus? She asked. I said, yeah, of course, because who wouldn't want a free grade? But then her expression changed to something I couldn't read. She explained that since I was the only student who showed concern for her well being, she wanted to give me a special choice. I could take the A+ for myself, but she'd tell.

When did your friends realize you weren't starving yourself? We're halfway through freshman year and my friends still grabbed my wrist to show people how their fingers overlap or joke that I could share my metabolism with them. Not kidding. Last week my roommate Leah literally put extra fries on my plate when I wasn't looking because someone needs to feed you, babe. Finding this friend group three months into college felt like finally breathing. They adopted me instantly. Leah pulling me into their booth at the dining hall, Sophie looping her arm through mine at parties. At every party they joke I was their pocket sized friend. Leah makes comments like eat a burger skinny whenever we go out. For months it was relentless but weirdly affectionate. You're gonna blow away. Real women have her bones are for dogs. Every meal was commentary. How are you full already? Must be nice to eat whatever you want. from their guy friend group literally picked me up with one arm once just to prove he could. But it felt like belonging, like finally having friends who cared enough to tease me. Besides bringing up my celiac seems dramatic. I'd rather take the skinny jokes and be the friend who needs special accommodations. Then three weeks ago, something shifted. The comments stopped. No more eat a burger jokes. No more grabbing my wrists. Instead, they got weird, careful, like they were walking on eggshells. Leah started buying extra snacks for the Room, casually leaving them on my desk. Sophie stopped making the metabolism jokes with random compliments about my personality. Olivia began suggesting restaurants with lots of options. When we went out Thursday night, I'm coming back early from Bio Lab and I hear them through the door. Our whole crew is in there. Leah, Sophie, Olivia, Jade, Madison. They never hang without me. Saturday at the pregame, before everyone else shows up, Leah's saying we have to be supportive but direct. The signs were all there. Jade says she never finishes meals, goes to the bathroom right after eating. She's getting thinner. My heart stops. They think I'm bulimic. Madison adds something about nutrition labels and restrictive behavior. Leah's voice gets soft, talking about doing this with love. They're planning an intervention for me. I text Sam from home about what I just heard. She asks what they could possibly be staging an intervention for. And when I tell them they think I'm bulimic, she points out the obvious. It's because of my celiact, but they don't know about that. She tells me to just tell them. But I have a better idea. I'm going to make a point. Saturday arrives. I've been at the library all day, giving them time to set up. At 5:45, I hit up the only gluten.

Accidentally joined a girls only discord server and pretended to be a girl for 3 weeks. Now they wanna meet in person. I'm 22 and have basically zero experience talking to girls. Gaming is where I feel comfortable. Just bros on discord, grinding ranked, talking about KD ratios, and complaining about teammates. Last month I misclicked a discord invite my friend sent me. Instead of elite gamers, I joined Gamer Girls only. No toxic bros allowed. Uh. My first instinct was to leave immediately, but before I could exit, they started discussing advanced Valorant Strats I'd never heard of. I muted my mic and listened, completely stunned. When Megan asked why I was quiet, I panicked and said my mic was broken. Then Maya asked about my rank and I accidentally squeaked out diamond in the highest voice possible. Dead silence for what felt like forever. Then Jessica burst out laughing. Girl, you sound like you've been chain smoking since you were 12. What happened to your voice? They assumed I was a girl with an unusually deep voice. In my panic, I just went with it instead of correcting them. That was three weeks ago. Now I'm Alex. They think it's short for Alexandra, and we play together every single night from around eight PM m to midnight. Here's where it gets weird. I'm actually good at being a girl online. I listen more instead of immediately offering solutions. I'm way less toxic when we lose rounds and I Ask questions instead of pretending I already know everything. Maya taught me movement techniques and crosshair positioning that boosted my KD from a pathetic 0.8 to two point one. Megan got me into cozy indie games like Stardew Valley that I'd never admit to my guy friends that I actually love. Jessica and I stay up until 3:00am talking about everything. Relationship problems, career stress, family drama, fears about the future. These conversations were deeper than anything I'd ever had with my guy friends. No posturing, no competition, just genuine support. Maya was struggling with her programming bootcamp, and I actually helped her debug code for hours. Megan was dealing with workplace harassment, and we all brainstorm solutions together. When Jessica's mom was in the hospital, we organized a gaming Marathon to keep her distracted. But yesterday, Jessica dropped a bomb. There's a gaming convention next weekend. We should totally meet up. All three of them were instantly excited about meeting up. They started planning matching outfits, booking hotel rooms at the same place, king dinner reservations at this Korean BBQ place they've been wanting to try. I spent that entire night researching voice training tutorials on YouTube and wondering if I could somehow pull off showing up in a wig and makeup. I watched videos about feminine body language, practiced walking differently in my room, and even looked up makeup tutorials for beginners. The complete absurdity of the situation hit me around 2:00am. I was seriously planning to dress In full drag, just to maintain a lie with my three best friends. So I made a decision the next night, during our usual Minecraft session. I

When did your sibling realise they were wrong for calling mom a useless housewife? Even before my parents signed the divorce papers, my older sister Cameron announced, I'm living with dad. He's got the corporate job making six figures. Mom's just a useless house life who's been doing nothing for the past 15 years. I watched Mom's face crumple just slightly before she forced to smile. That's okay, sweetie, whatever makes you comfortable. Cameron rolled her eyes. It's not about comfort. It's about being smart. Dad's the one with actual money. She looked at me like I was an idiot when I said I'd stay with mom, enjoy eating canned soup for dinner every night, she said. Dragging her suitcase down the stairs, mom watched her hop in Dad's car quietly and apologized to me for getting the wrong parent. I hugged her. You got this, mom. What I didn't know was that those words were the exact catalyst she needed to prove everyone wrong. Mom landed a job at target, not exactly in a managerial position like dad, but she didn't stop there. Every evening after cooking us dinner, she took online certifications, project management, Quickbooks, data entry, whatever she could get her hands on. And within months, she moved from restocking supplies to a fancy new office job, bookkeeping for a local contractor, and later worked her way up to managing the entire back office operation. I was seriously so proud of her. Meanwhile, Dad's situation was completely Different. He couldn't balance his corporate job with actually parenting Cameron. He started missing meetings to drive her places, called in sick when she had school events. He was spending hundreds on takeout every night, hiring cleaners weekly, paying for babysitters. Even though Cameron was 17 and the last time I saw him, he looked extremely frustrated. After months of repeated offences at work, his performance tanked and the promotion he'd been promised disappeared. And my sister completely oblivious to it because as long as she had dad's credit card in her pocket, why would she care, right? That is until mom started her own virtual assistant business. She snagged her first client and quickly started handling five at a time. And I helped her however I could. When our clients reached beyond 20, mom hired her first employee, another mom who needed flexible work. The mom cried when she received the news. You're a blessing, she told her. They both worked hard to expand and hire more moms. And eventually, two years in, she had 12 employees and a real office space of her own, making more money than dad ever brought in. And as for dad, he unfortunately got laid off the same month mom signed the lease on her office. And my sister Cameron, following the scent of money, quickly jumped ship. After dad lost the nice townhouse in the city, my sister called us. Can I stay with you guys a bit? She asked in the Sweetest voice. Mom immediately said, yes, of course, family is family. Cameron arrived with her suitcases to find our house completely transformed. Mom had renovated everything. New kitchen, finished basement, the garage converted to a home office. And the cars in the driveway had upgraded from Mom's rusty old truck to a beautiful silver BMW M4. And working under mom, I managed to snag a recently released JCW Mini Cooper. My sister's jaw absolutely dropped. Oh, my god, mom, you're so cool. She smiled. Thanks, sweetie. While Cameron went on and on about how luxurious everything was now.

What's the funniest way you've seen someone ruin their reputation? My dad loved making fun of me and my siblings for being scared of horror movies. You guys are babies. I've never been scared of anything in my life. Every single time we got freaked out, he'd roll his eyes, shake his head, and act like he was some fearless action hero. He'd sit there completely unfazed, saying stuff like, this isn't even scary. We were practically hiding under the couch, and I had enough. I made it my personal mission to prove that man wrong. One night, he was watching a horror movie with my brother and sister. The room was pitch black. They were all locked in, fully focused on the screen. And I knew it was time. I crept up behind the couch, waited for the perfect moment. Then I struck. I grabbed his shoulders and let out the most demonic horror movie monster scream I could. And this man, who claims that nothing scares him, scream like a little girl. Not just a normal scream, not just a startled yell. I mean a high pitched, full volume horror movie victim scream. He jumped so hard he practically launched himself across the entire room. I've never seen a human being move that fast. Dude went from sitting on the couch to being halfway up the stairs in 0.2 second. For a second, we all just stared, and then we lost it. My brother was on the floor. Wheezing. My sister was crying. I was gasping for air. And my dad, he was just standing there, completely frozen, processing. Then he realized the guy who never gets scared had just launched himself into orbit over a jump scare that wasn't even in the movie. And from that moment on, he was done. Every time we watch a horror movie, one of us leans over and whispers, we can turn it off if you get too scared. What makes it better is that we got it on video. And every time he tries to act tough, we just play it back. Reputation gone forever.

When did you realise? You raised your daughter right? My daughter Elia destroyed our neighbour's face with a baseball bat. I was in the middle of a work meeting when my phone lit up with a call from my neighbour Roman. His voice was shaking with fury. Your daughter Elia is psychotic. She attacked me with a baseball bat. I was just checking on her like you asked and she broke my effing nose! The cops are already here. My blood ran cold. Elia was a straight A student and had never been in a fight in her life. I ran to my car and started driving. The 20 minute drive home felt like hours, my mind racing through every possible scenario. Roman's words kept echoing in my head. Psychotic attack act. Broke my nose. What could have possibly happened? By the time I reached our driveway, my shirt was soaked with sweat. The scene that greeted me was even worse than I'd imagined. Two police cruisers were parked outside with their lights flashing and half the neighborhood had gathered on their lawns to stare. Roman was on our front porch and was holding a towel to what was clearly a broken nose. His white polo shirt was stained red and he was gesturing wildly at two officers who were taking notes. She. He needs to be locked up! He was shouting. This is assault with a deadly weapon! I want charges pressed! Elia sat on our front lawn with Her knees pulled to her chest, staring at the grass. She looked so small, so defeated. The female officer approached me as I got out of the car. Sir, your neighbor claims your daughter attacked him unprovoked with a baseball bat. If he presses charges, we're looking at aggravated assault. That could mean juvenile detention. Stomach dropped. Roman saw me and immediately started ranting. She's violent, unhinged. I was just checking on her like you asked, making sure she got home safe from school, and she came at me like a wild animal. Look at my face. My nose is broken. I might need surgery. The male officer showed me photos. They'd taken Roman's injuries. His nose was definitely broken, already starting to bruise. Your daughter hasn't said a word since we arrived, the officer said quietly. We need to know what happened here. I walked past Roman, ignoring his continued shouting about pressing charges and teaching violent children a lesson. Then I knelt down beside Elia on the grass and gently put my hand on her shoulder. She flinched, but didn't look up. Elia, sweetheart, I need you to tell me exactly what happened. Every detail. She finally raised her head, and I saw her eyes were red from crying. But there was something else there, too. Anger. Maybe even disgust. I was in my room, she said, her voice barely a whisper.

What are some very obvious signs someone is into you? 1. Honestly, I got rejected by a girl who seemed to send very obvious signs, so I don't know anything anymore. 2. I've heard you can tell by where they put their feet. Like if they put their feet behind their ears, they really like you. 3. A girl flirted with me in French, stole my bag under the table as a joke, wanted to arm wrestle, and sat in the pub with me for 7 hours. She could have been Canadian so I never knew if she liked me or not. Second date is today. 4. I tell my wife about a weird interaction I had with a waitress, lady at the store, etcetera. Then she tells me that woman was hitting on me. Apparently I'm oblivious. Five. Looking back on my time in college, I got some pretty clear signs that I completely missed. If a girl invites you back to her dorm because she forgot something and then can't remember what she was going back to get, and then sits on her bed and just kind of looks at you, that's a pretty clear sign. I think about that occasionally. I can't believe I missed that one. 6. Laughing at everything I say. It's how I recognized my girlfriend. Like me, I could say virtually anything and I could see her laughing. 7. If you see that person hiding in a tree outside your window. 8. I Like things to be very clear and obvious, so I insist on waiting for them to issue me a section 3.02 notice intention to pursue romantically, which will set out their detailed five year plan for us and describe the boundaries of their proposed pursuit, including likes, dislikes, and information on any allergies. Still waiting, but one day I'm sure my luck will turn.
NA

What happened when you met a deaf girl at your cousin's wedding? Three years ago, at my cousin's wedding, I knocked over this girl's drink, reaching across the buffet table. I apologized for 30 seconds straight before realizing she was pointing at her ears and signing something I didn't understand. My cousin texted me later that night. That was Annalise. She lost her hearing from meningitis when she was six. He sent her Instagram. She asked about the guy who kept talking to himself at the say. I scrolled through videos of her signing stories, her face animated and expressive. In one video, she taught basic signs. I watched it over and over, trying to copy her hand movements. She looks so confident, so comfortable in her silence. I messaged her two days later. I'm the idiot who wouldn't stop apologizing at the wedding. Can I buy you a replacement drink? She replied with laughing emojis. You mean the guy who gave a whole speech to a deaf person, then added, yes, but only if you bring a notepad this time? At the coffee shop, we typed messages back and forth on our phones. Annalise told me her parents never Learned ASL after she went deaf. They still think hearing aids solve everything, like glasses for your ears. When she laughed, her whole face lit up. I forgot to read her next message until she waved her hand at me. Stop staring, weirdo! I typed back. Sorry, you're distracting. She Rolled her eyes but smiled. We stayed until they kicked us out of closing. After that date, I downloaded every ASL app I could find. I practiced finger spelling during my commute, signed to myself in mirrors. My roommate caught me signing in my sleep. Dude, are you cursing someone out? I was apparently signing banana repeatedly. Annalise sent me daily sign tutorials. Today's phrase, I'm hopeless at this. I sent videos of my attempts. She responded, you just signed, I'm pregnant with fish. Please try again. Within six months, I could hold conversations. Annalise introduced me to her deaf friends at a game night. Everyone signed so fast my eyes couldn't keep. But her friend signed something that made everyone laugh. Annalise translated. She says, you signed with an accent. Like a baby accent. I tried signing back. At least I'm trying. More laughter. Annalise fixed my hands. You just said you're crying. Close enough. Two years in, we moved in together. I was fluent by then. Our apartment peaceful, except for her cat, who meowed at shadows. We signed everything, rarely using our voices. Annalise preferred it that way. Said signing felt more natural than trying to read lips all day. But sometimes when she was focused on something else, reading or cooking or painting her nails, I started talking out loud to her. Just little things. At first, you look beautiful in that light. She never reacted. Had no idea. Then it became bigger. Confessions. I wanna Marry you someday. She kept stirring pasta sauce. You're everything I never knew I needed. She adjusted the heat completely unaware. It became my secret ritual. When she was absorbed in her phone, I'd practice proposing. Annalise, will you marry me? She scrolled through TikTok. I've loved you since you laughed at my terrible signing. She double tapped a video. I bought a ring. It's hidden in my gym bag. She never looked up. I practiced in the shower, in my car. Whenever she couldn't see my lips moving. The words got easier each time. Sometimes I'd tell her about my day, my fears, my dreams. All these one sided conversations she never knew about. One evening, her best friend Graceland visited. Signed rapidly in the kitchen while I pretended to read. I caught pieces of their conversation in my peripheral vision. Annalise was signing emotionally about something. Graceland kept encouraging her. Then I saw it clearly. Annalise, sign

The worst way to spot a toxic relationship. My boyfriend used to make me apologize so much that sorry, sorry, sorry had become my most spoken punchline. I used to time my showers for when Nolan left for the gym because the sound of running water annoyed him. It's like nails on a chalkboard, he'd say, even from two rooms away. My friend Esme once asked why I whispered on our phone calls, and I couldn't explain that. Nolan said my voice was too shrill. Whenever I got excited when I cooked, I'd apologize preemptively for the smell, the sound of chopping, the cabinet doors closing. Nolan would sigh and say I was lucky he was so patient with me, that other guys wouldn't put up with someone so naturally annoying. Oh, the curse of a first relationship. Then one day, Esme invited me to her apartment for wine night while Nolan was out of town for work. I almost canceled three times. Text, typed, and deleted. Nolan always said my friends were toxic influences who enabled my worst qualities, but something about his empty side of the bed made me brave. Or maybe just lonely. Esme's boyfriend Remy was there when I arrived, which made my stomach clench. I can go, I offered immediately, already backing toward the door. He's just leaving for poker night, Esme laughed, pulling me inside. But Remy was pouring wine for all of us, asking about my work, actually listening to my story about The nightmare client. He laughed at the right parts and asked follow up questions. When Esme interrupted to add her own work or story, he just smiled and said, babe, babe, you tell it better without a trace of irritation. Twenty minutes in, Esme knocked over her wine glass, reaching for the remote. Dark red merlot spread across their cream carpet like blood. I froze, my body automatically bracing for impact, but Remy just said, I'll grab the club soda and kissed her forehead as he passed. No sighing? No. How could you be so careless? No silent treatment that would last three days. Esme wasn't frantically scrubbing while apologizing. She was laughing about being a klutz while Remy worked on the stain. And he was laughing too, telling me about the time he dropped an entire lasagna on the same carpet. When Esme got excited telling a story about her horrible boss, her voice got louder, more animated. Remy watched her with this soft expression, like her enthusiasm was something precious. You're so cute when you're fired up, he said. Not you're being dramatic or lower your voice or why do you always have to be so intense? When they disagreed about what movie to watch, Remy said, you chose last time, but honestly, I'll watch whatever makes you happy. Esme put on some ROM com and Remy pulled her closer, playing with her hair. Halfway through, Esme said she was cold. Remy got up to get her favorite Blanket without being asked, brought her tea without her mentioning it, remembered she liked two sugars and oat milk. You're spoiling me, Esme said. Good, Remy replied. When Esme started getting sleepy, slumping against Remy, he adjusted his position to make her more comfortable, even though his arm was probably falling asleep. He caught me staring and smiled. Three years and I still can't believe I got this lucky, he said quietly, so as not to wake her. Before he left for poker, Remy did the dishes from dinner without being asked, took out the trash, and left a sticky note on the coffee maker that said love you, beautiful for Esme to find in the morning. Drive safe, Esme called out. Always do. Text you when I get there, he called back. No accusations about checking up on him? No. Why don't you trust me? Just easy care for each other's peace of mind when I got home that night.
NA

What's the smartest way you've tested your daughter's boyfriend? I pretended I didn't speak English around him for six months and heard everything he said when he thought I couldn't understand. My daughter Emma started dating this guy Kyle last year. Nice looking kid. Always super polite around me and my wife. Maybe too polite. He'd bring flowers every time he came over. Always offered to help with dishes, called me sir non stop. Something felt rehearsed about it. I was born in Brazil, but moved here when I was 10. No accent at all anymore, but my parents taught me to never lose my Portuguese. One night at dinner, Emma mentioned that Kyle was taking Spanish in college. I got this crazy idea. Next time he came over, I pretended I barely spoke English. Just smiled, nodded, and spoke Portuguese with Emma translating. Said I'd had a stroke that affected my language center. Emma was confused, but played along. When I explained my plan in private, she thought I was being ridiculous, but agreed to help. The first few weeks, Kyle was exactly the same. Super respectful, patient with the language barrier. He even downloaded a translation app. By month, two cracks started showing. When Emma left to use the bathroom, he'd mutter things under his breath. This food is disgusting. How long is this dinner going to take? Once I heard him quietly mock my accent to himself. I pretended not to notice, just smiled and offered more Food. When Emma's birthday came around, Kyle showed up with an expensive bracelet. Later, I overheard him on the phone in our backyard. Yeah, I returned the cheap one and got the silver one instead. Her dad's loaded. Gotta look the part. That was interesting. I'm comfortable, but definitely not loaded. We live in a normal three bedroom house. I drive a 2016 Subaru. One Saturday, Emma had a shift at the hospital. She's in nursing school. Kyle came by anyway, said he left his charger. I let him in, still doing my broken English act while I. I pretended to watch a Portuguese soccer game. He took pictures of our mail, our investment statements. Even opened my desk drawer when he thought I wasn't looking. The next week, I accidentally left fake bank statements showing a negative balance and massive debt on the kitchen counter just to see what would happen. Three days later, Kyle told Emma he needed space and wasn't sure about their relationship. Said he wanted to find himself before getting serious with anyone. Emma was heartbroken, but suspicious. She asked if my test had shown anything. I told her everything I'd heard. We waited to see if Kyle would come back once the fake bank statement and disappeared.
